title: china wet markets coronavirus world knees
story: EVEN for a carnivore like me, the images are gruesome and disgusting enough to consider whether I’ll eat meat again.A smorgasbord of dogs being boiled alive, bats served on sticks like lollipops, kittens slaughtered, rats fried and giant snakes carved up for human consumption, with the blood splattering everywhere.There are no hygiene standards. Cross-contamination is rampant. The animal cruelty is off the scale.Bears, tigers,  wolf cubs, crocodiles, hedgehogs and turtles are not spared in this notorious wildle food trade, either.Now the despicable wet markets used by some Chinese people — markets already responsible for the Sars outbreak in  — have finally brought the world to its knees.Scientists have established that it is highly likely Covid- was linked to a notorious live animal market in Wuhan.Gene sequencing analysis shows the new coronavirus probably started in bats and was transferred to humans via the scaly anteater the pangolin.So why is there so little outrage about the wet markets that we know have the potential to cause catastrophic outcomes to human health Even Donald Trump — slammed for branding Covid- the “Chinese virus” — avoided criticising the wet markets when prompted during a press conference at the White House on Wednesday.Maybe that’s because the moment someone tries to speak up they are accused of racism.That happened to reality star and retail entrepreneur Luisa Zissman earlier this week when she posted a video on Instagram of a wet market and called for them to be “banned completely”.After the usual social media outrage, she told me: “I wholeheartedly disagree with this particular part of Chinese culture, but that does not make me racist.” It should be remembered there are many campaigners within China desperately trying to get the wet markets banned too.After all, the addition of more exotic animals only dates back to the s, as the ruling communist party struggled to feed the population and million people perished in what became known as the great famine.By , the ironically named Wildle Protection Law encouraged industrial-level breeding of the likes of bears, bats and turtles to be sold through wet markets. And that’s when the viruses began to form.When the Sars crisis was linked to a wet market in southern China, officials shut it down and made wildle farming illegal. But they reversed the decision just a few months later.As of  it was a £billion industry, mainly because the rich and the powerful pay copious quantities of money to eat rare wildle as they believe  claims about their role in Chinese medicine.Now with coronavirus spreading, the government has again temporarily banned wildle trading and shut down wet markets.But it’s not permanent yet — and it must be.We already know that the early Chinese cover-up of Covid-, which makes Chernobyl look like a misdemeanour, resulted in the disease’s rapid spread.In fact,China had taken early action experts reckon the number of coronavirus cases could have been cut by  per cent, making its rampage all over the globe far less likely.The new illness was directly linked to the infamous wildle market in Wuhan on December , but it wasn’t until New Year’s Eve that the World Health Organisation was informed and the site closed.The brave Chinese doctors who tried to spread the word about Covid- were shut down by the authorities too, and early testing was stopped and samples  destroyed.I have no doubt the Chinese government has blood on its hands over coronavirus.And saying that now, at the peak of the health crisis, is not the time to tackle the issue is wrong.We must have this uncomfortable discussion while our anger is raw and the pain  all too real.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.I DON’T have enough superlatives to describe my adoration for Lady Gaga.No pop star of her generation has been more consistently savvy, smart or, for that matter, talented.So it pains me to so deeply disagree with her decision to delay the release of her highly anticipated new album Chromatica, which was due to drop on April , in the middle of quarantine hell.In fact, I actually think the delay is quite selfish.Thanks to the technological advances in streaming, listening to new music is one of the few activities we can engage in collectively without having to leave the house. Gaga wrote that: “It just doesn’t feel right to me to release this album with all that is going on during this global pandemic.”Instead she wants us all to focus on “finding solutions”, such as providing medical equipment and school meals.All very good aims, of course.But what the world also needs now is music, sweet music, to unite us and, frankly, distract us.She’s also made a strategic error, given she had a captive audience with time on their hands at home to stream to their heart’s content.This is the time for the UK to show that, eight decades on, we still have the Blitz spirit in our blood.Many of our parents or grandparents were sent to the front line to fight Hitler.All most of us have to do is put our lives temporarily on hold while scoffing Domino’s pizza and watching Netflix.I don’t for a second underestimate the signicance of such a call, by the way.These are dark days and there is a growing coronavirus-shaped cloud over our daily lives right now, causing extreme stress and anxiety.It’s so easy to feel angry and uncertain and tearful and depressed.Like you, I’ve been through the gamut of emotions while practising social distancing.However, that is simply not an excuse not to try to  carry on with your normal lives.It won’t be for ever. In fact, the sooner we do this properly, the sooner this nightmare will be over.At such a trying time it is imperative we celebrate the brilliant work being done by so many to keep society running.So thank you to the doctors, the nurses, the NHS workers, the first responders, the supermarket staff, the cleaners, the bus drivers, the Tube staff, the delivery drivers, the journalists and anyone  who NEEDS to keep working to keep our society going.They’ll thank the rest of us for doing our part too and staying indoors.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dan wootton harry meghan hollywood move
story: GENUINELY mind-blowing.That is the reaction amongst royals and courtiers about Harry and Meghan’s decision to move to Los Angeles in the middle of an unprecedented international health crisis, rather thanto do their duty in Britain.At the very least, it’s a massive PR blunder.Just think about this for a moment: The Duke has decided to leave the Commonwealth to set up home in Hollywood at the exact moment his grandmother is trapped in self-isolation within Windsor Castle because of her age and his dad is in Scotland battling Covid-.The Sussexes had an amazing opportunity to prove to the public here that when the going gets tough they will still be there for their family, the institution of the monarchy and their loyal subjects too.Instead, yet again, they’ve shown their priority is their new Hollywood mates and a lestyle most of us can only dream of.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus dr hilary hot drinks
story: WE may be in the grip of a national health crisis but one of Britain’s most respected doctors is here to tell you what you should – and shouldn’t – be doing.Many of you are understandably worried about yourself and your loved ones catching the virus, and more than , of you have contacted us with questions for Dr Hilary Jones.Dr Hilary – health editor for ITV’s Good Morning Britain and Lorraine – is back once again responding to the queries that are flooding in from Sun readers. Today, he busts some myths surrounding the coronavirus – and gives tips on how everyone can help to prevent its spread . . .Q: I’ve heard hot drinks can kill the virus. Is this correct A: There is absolutely no truth whatsoever in that, unfortunately. People are reading all sorts of information and perhaps they have got this from the fact the virus is affected by high temperatures. But hot drinks would have no effect on the virus in the eyes and nose, which is often where it gets in. There is also no evidence hot drinks could prevent the virus or make it more mild.Q: Will the UV light from the sun help stop the coronavirus A: Ultraviolet light can weaken and kill the virus because UV radiation can destroy lots of microorganisms. That is why it is OK for people to go out in the fresh air and exercise — but not in groups of more than two people from the same household. Butyou already have the virus in your nose and throat UV light won’t have any effect.Q: You said you shouldn’t take ibuprofen. Ginger has anti-inflammatory properties too. Is it still safe to eat it A: Herbs such as ginger and garlic do have anti-inflammatory properties but the effects are so mild they would not have an appreciable effect. There is no reason to avoid culinary herbs.Q. If I get the virus, what should I do A: Stay at home and self-isolate for seven daysyou live alone or for  daysyou live with other people. Treat your symptoms as you would with any other upper-respiratory infection. Take paracetamol to help bring down your temperature, use cough medicine to help ease your cough, use lozenges or a spray for your sore throat, andyou have a bunged-up nose, use a decongestant. Drink plenty of fluids.Q. Should I still take my child for their routine vaccination A: Yes, you should still take your child. Routine immunisations continue to protect children from all the usual infections. They are being held in a safe clinical setting.Q. I am heavily pregnant and due to have my baby in hospital in a few weeks. Is this still safe A: Antenatal and obstetrics care is continuing. All midwery teams are taking every precaution for services to continue as normal. No one needs to be frightened going into hospital to have a baby. Hospitals are a safe clinical environment and you will be discharged as soon as is appropriate and practically possible.Q: We are waiting on a cancer diagnosis for our daughter. Will they delay starting treatment because of the virus A: No. Serious and emergency treatments will continue despite the virus outbreak. This cannot be postponed.Q: The streets are now full of runners and some push past me on the pavement. Can they pass the virus through their sweat A: This is a respiratory virus, transmitted through droplets in the air we breathe out and through sneezing. Our hands can be contaminated and when we put our hands to our face that’s how the virus gets into the body. Sweat and blood are not thought to transmit the virus.Q: I’ve always had a weak immune system and I seem to catch everything going. How much at risk am I A: There is no evidence that people who are prone to catching ordinary colds are more susceptible to coronavirus. Just take the necessary precautions and keep on physically distancing from others.Q: I ride a motorbike. Is there any reason I can’t A: In theory there is no reason why you can’t continue to ride. But the main risk is of you getting injured and requiring hospital treatment. Certainly, the last thing we want to do is overload the NHS with injuries that can be avoided so keep the consequences of what you do in mind.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Q: My husband is a self-employed gardener working on his own. Is he safe to go to do someone’s garden when he has no contact with the people A: While it sounds very strict, the Government’s advice is now clear. That is that everybody should stay at home unless their work is absolutely essential. Evenyour husband’s work involves travelling by car on the road, needing to fill up with petrol for example, that increases human-to-human contact, which is how the virus is transmitted.Q: I’m  and a volunteer driver for cancer patients. Is it safe for me to still be doing my voluntary work A: While you do a wonderful job, your age puts you in the vulnerable category and you should stop doing what you’re doing. We now have more than , NHS volunteer responders who will all be younger than you and can take up this kind of work. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: land army feed nation lockdown
story: ENVIRONMENT Secretary George Eustice has called for a ‘Land Army’ to help feed the nation during the coronavirus crisis.With the nation on lockdown there are fears there will not be enough seasonal workers to pick crops during the summer months.Mr Eustice is calling for Brits to work in the fields, echoing the , women who joined the land army in World War Two to help feed the nation.Mr Eustice said: “Our farmers are doing a fantastic job of feeding the nation during this immensely challenging time.“I have been speaking with industry today and in the last week about the critically important issue of seasonal workers, who usually come from Europe to pick fruit and vegetables.“We need to mobilise the British workforce to fill that gap and make sure our excellent fruit and vegetables are on people’s plates over the summer months.There are already brilliant recruitment efforts underway by industry and I would encourage as many people as possible to sign up.“We will also be looking at other ways to make sure farmers have support they need ahead of the busy harvest months, while also keeping workers safe and protected.”It comes as Ocado group Chair Lord Rose called for more people to work in the food industry, saying: “We need more human beings to come into our supply chains.“There are jobs around, let’s retrain them, redeploy them and get them out into the field.”The National Farmer Union has warned of the shortage of workers which could see good food left rotting in the fields.An NFU spokesperson said: “Growers that rely on seasonal workers to pick, pack and grade our fruit and veg are extremely concerned about the impact coronavirus measures may have on their ability to recruit workers this year.The industry is already working hard to promote available roles on farm locally, recognising that this could help those who unfortunately find themselves out of work.“We are urging the government to address this situation as soon as possible and to implement any solution as a matter of urgency.Tory MP Ian Liddell-Grainger, who represents for Bridgwater and West Somerset, has called for a scheme that allows farmers to pay workers in cash or via bank transfer to quicken the process.He said: “We cannot load farmers up with more onerous paperwork because they have more than enough on their plates at the moment.These are desperate times and the Government is tearing up the rules on a daily basis to get us through them, so a few more torn ones arent going to make a heap of dference.The dference this scheme could make, however, is that between the nation continuing to be fed and some serious and prolonged food shortages.The scheme to find farm workers is called Feed the Nation.It is run jointly by labour providers HOPS, Fruitful Jobs and Concordia with support from the NFU.Since the start of the crisis it has already received more than , applications.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us title: coronavirus spreads week symptoms
story: Professor Peter Openshaw, past President of the British Society for Immunology, tells how the virus spreads in just seven days.YOU arrange to meet a friend. You don’t know, but ten days ago their brother went to a pub where he caught the virus from the waiter.Later, your friend’s brother coughed into his hand before opening the door to your friend.Your friend talks to you and spittle touches your face.THE virus is working its way into the moist lining of your nose. You are not contagious just yet.Your body’s cells are mounting a response, which the virus is trying to overcome. There’s a battle going.If the virus manages to take down the first defences, it can then break out and spread.STILL feeling well, you continue meeting with friends and family.The virus is now established inside you, hijacking cells and turning them into virus factories.You don’t kiss your -year-old aunty goodbye, but you do use the toilet. You flush and leave the virus on the handle.FEELING fine, but you don’t know your natural defences are down.You itch your nose at the supermarket then touch a shopping basket, a box of cereal and the card reader.By now you are emitting a cloud of infectious droplets and you’ve been within a metre of at least  other shoppers.THE first symptoms appear. The thought of dinner makes you feel a bit sick. You feel tired and want to sleep.Feeling unwell, you call a dog walker and book her to take your dog out. She agrees, grateful for the work.You give her a £ note and the odd few hundred thousand virus particles.YOU have a raging fever and ache all over. You feel sicker than you’ve ever been before.The fever is actually a sign that your immune system is working to fight the virus by creating a hostile environment.You wish you had stayed indoors sooner and been less blasé about catching it.THANKFULLY, the fever, cough and sore throat are where the symptoms end for most people.By day seven, your immune system is in full swing and will be able to destroy the virus allowing you to recover. Others — including some you have been in contact with — will not be so lucky.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sports direct mike ashley apologises stores open coronavirus
story: SPORTS Direct owner Mike Ashley today apologised for his ill-judged and poorly-timed attempt to keep stores open amid the coronavirus crisis.The sports equipment retailer boss was widely slammed after telling staff to head into work as instructed, minutes after the government ordered all non-essential stores to close immediately.And in an open letter today, the billionaire boss said he was deeply apologetic over the demands sent to staff.He said: In hindsight, our emails to the Government were ill-judged and poorly-timed, when they clearly had much greater pressures than ours to deal with.He added: I am deeply apologetic about the misunderstandings of the last few days.We will learn from this and will try not to make the same mistakes in the future.Sports Direct had initially claimed that its position selling sporting and fitness equipment was vital during a lockdown to help stop the spread of coronavirus but it shut its doors after pressure from MPs.And Mr Ashley has now thrown his support behind the NHS - offering the companys entire fleet of lorries for deliveries.He said: Outside of Frasers Group, I have offered our support to the NHS and we are poised and ready for what hat offer is accepted, with our entire fleet of lorries at their disposal - to help deliver medical equipment and supplies.This offer is not limited to the NHS but all key workforces across the Government. We will help wherever possible.Our intentions were only to seek clarity from the Government as to whether we should keep some of our stores open we would never have acted against their advice.In hindsight, our emails to the Government were ill-judged and poorly-timed, when they clearly had much greater pressures than ours to deal with.On top of this, our communications to our employees and the public on this was poor.There has been no dress rehearsal for what we as a nation are currently tackling, and I for one am immensely proud of how our Government, our NHS and all of our key workers have handled the situation so far.I would especially like to thank my Fraseers Group employees who have stood by the business in dficult times before and are doing so again currently.We are working very hard to save our business, so that we can continue to be one of the biggest employers on the UK high street once this pandemic has passed.Outside of Frasers Group, I have offered our support to the NHS and we are poised and ready for what hat offer is accepted, with our entire fleet of lorries at their disposal - to help deliver medical equipment and supplies.This offer is not limited to the NHS but all key workforces across the Government. We will help wherever possible.Finally, to reiterate, I am deeply apologetic about the misunderstandings of the last few days.We will learn from this and will try not to make the same mistakes in the future.I strongly encourage everyone to follow the Governments advice, stay safe and healthy through these challenging times, not least my employees.Kind regards,Mike AshleyIt comes after Sports Direct staff were ordered to slap increased price tags on lines of home fitness goods.Pricing documents seen by PA news agency show that an Everlast kg kettle bell has gone up from £. to £., although the original ticket price will still say £..This is because of the complicated way the controversial company displays its pricing, which is often with a reduced price sticker alongside the original price tag, making it unclear what price a product was ever sold at.Hundreds of Brits have turned to home exercise equipment to help them keep fit while being ordered by the government to stay at home.Retailers have been warned by the competitions watchdog not to use the crisis to push up prices or risk facing being fined.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.The group had wrote to all workers within  minutes of Prime Minister Boris Johnsons decision on Monday to shut down non-essential retailers, telling them its position selling sporting and fitness equipment made it a vital asset during a national shutdown.In the original letter, Mr Wootton said: Against the backdrop of the closure of gyms the demand for these types of products has increased exponentially as the population looks to maintain a healthy lestyle.Consequently, we are uniquely well placed to help keep the UK as fit and healthy as possible during this crisis and thus our Sports Direct and Evans Cycles stores will remain open where possible to allow us to do this .Labour MP Jess Phillips also criticised the appeal to keep stores open, tweeting: Massive mugs notwithstanding there is nothing people cannot live without in Sports Direct.Rival retailers such as JD Sports have confirmed that stores will remain shut until Government guidance changes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus food shortage un
story: THE CORONAVIRUS crisis could cause food shortages around the world, the UN’s food body has warned.But people should not panic buy during the outbreak as this will only make matters worse, says chief economist of the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation, Maximo Torero.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHe said: “Iniduals should only buy what they need to avoid food waste.”Although harvests have been good, a shortage of field workers and governments banning exports means the shortages could appear in the next few weeks.Mr Torero told thethat restricting food flow is “the worst thing” governments can do.He said: “Now is not the time for restrictions or putting in place trade barriers.“Now is the time to protect the flow of food around the world.”Kazakhstan has already banned exports of wheat flour and is restricting buckwheat and vegetables, according to a Bloomberg report.Vietnam, the world’s third-biggest rice exporter, has temporarily suspended rice export contracts.Russia, the world’s biggest wheat exporter, may also threaten to restrict exports.Torero warns: “Trade barriers will create extreme volatility”“[They] will make the situation worse. That’s what we observe in food crises.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Problems are expected to get worse over the following two months as key fruit and vegetables come into season as this produce relies on pickers.Torero said: “We need to be careful not to break the food value chain and the logistics or we will be looking at problems with fresh vegetables and fruits soon.“Fruit and vegetables are also very labour intensive,the labour force is threatened because people can’t move then you have a problem.”He added: Coronavirus is affecting the labour force and the logistical problems are becoming very important.Mr Torero says governments need to act now to stop a food crisis.“We need to have policies in place so the labour force can keep doing their job.“Protect people too, but we need the labour force.“Major countries have yet to implement these sorts of policies to ensure that food can keep moving.”This comes amid fears the virus could spark also global paracetamol crisis as India limits its drug exports.While The Sun revealed that France seized two lorries carrying , face masks for the NHS after banning them from being shipped abroad, The Sun revealed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kim jong un aide vanishes replaced sister
story: The North Korean dictator, , appears to have orchestrated another power sht within his cabinet reportedly sacking high-flying diplomat Choe Son-hui, .Last seen in December, Choe is an impressive negotiator who climbed the precarious ladder of Pyongyang politics impressing foreign politicians with her perfect English and strong personality, reports The Times.She was a personal favourite of despot Kim who appointed her vice-minister of foreign affairs – and as recently as last October she was seen giving the ruthless leader “on-the-spot guidance”.There is no evidence that Choe has been killed in one of the young dictators infamous purges.However, her continued absence from state media reports suggests she has been abruptly replaced with Kims most trusted ally Kim Yo-jong, his younger sister.Experts believe her departure is part of a continued power sht away from the foreign ministry towards the United Front Department - the spy ision responsible for relations with South Korea.Writing for the NK News, journalist Wang Son-taek said: “The sudden disappearance of Choe should be interpreted as a sign . . . that she may have lost . . . trust, and one notable development during the period of her fading was the . . . shrinking presence of the foreign ministry itself.”This is yet more evidence of the growing ambition of Kim Yo-jong – the youngest child of late-North Korean dictator Kim Jong-il.Much like her brother, she was privately educated in Switzerland and often appears by her siblings side at well-orchestrated events.She is currently responsible for cultivating Kim Jong-uns public image and is officially the vice-minister of the propaganda and agitation department.Earlier this month, Kim Yo-jong showed her increasing power within the government by publicly mocking South Korea as a frightened dog barking as the North launched live-fire military drills.The military exercises, the first for three months, were condemned by the South Korean government — but Ms Kim dismissed this as mentally challenged.She said: As far as I know, the South side is also fond of joint military exercises and it is preoccupied with all the disgusting acts like purchasing ultra-modern military hardware.They meant they need to get militarily prepared but we should be discouraged from military exercises.Such a gangster-like assertion can never be expected from those with normal way of thinking.This was the first time Ms Kim has made a public statement and indicates her new status among the political hierarchy.Dubbed North Korea’s Ivanka Trump, Ms Kim kept a low profile until last year, when she was hand-picked to head up Pyongyangs propaganda department.Shes believed to be aged  and is said to have had a close relationship with brother from an early age.After studying in Switzerland between  and  she is believed to have attended the Kim Il-sung Military University while also later studying computer science.Our journalists strive for title: no eviction homes coroanvirus renters
story: Landlords WONT be able to kick Brits out of their homes during the coronavirus crisis under new Government measures.The Government has brought in a course of action protecting renters as the outbreak continues.In a huge boost for Britain’s . million renters, landlords will now have to give tenants three month noticethey plan on booting them out.This will apply in law until September  , with the three month notice period even extending furtherneeded.The protection covers most tenants in England and Wales against all grounds for evictions.All ongoing housing possession action is now also suspended, meaning no current case can see someone evicted.This will last for  days, but again could be extendedthe crisis rumbles on.Support has also been set aside to help renters pay, including cash as well as measures to help them negotiate with landlords during this dficult time.Landlords are also supported, with the Government earlier announcing a three month mortgage payment holiday to give then a break from paying.The housing market was all but frozen last night after the Government said all moves should be suspended.Buyers were urged to delay moving in and paying up to avoid breaking the rules on social distancing.A government spokesman said: Home buyers and renters should, as far as possible, delay moving home while emergency measures are in place to fight coronavirus.If moving is unavoidable for contractual reasons, people must follow advice on social distancing to minimise the spread of the virus.All parties should prioritise agreeing amicable arrangements to change move dates for iniduals in this group, or where someone in a chain is in this group.Banks had called for the property market to be frozen amid concerns over the economic crisis.It comes one day on from the Chancellor Rishi Sunak unveiling a bumper package of help for .million of Britains army of self-employed workers.Brits earning up to £, will be able to get up to title: coronavirus tests germany virus three hours
story: The test by Bosch can detect results in a hospital or GPs surgery - ruling out the need for samples to be sent off to the lab for analysis.It works by taking a swab from the patients throat or nose, inserting it into a prepared cartridge which is fed into a free-standing console.Known as the Vivalytic VRItest, it checks the patients sample for the SARS CoV- virus, which can lead to Covid-.Doctors will then get a direct result - either positive or negative - within as little as two and a half hours.At the moment, most of the commonly used tests take at least  hours to deliver a result following laboratory analysis.Dr Jochen Rupp, a Bosch product manager, told the : “It’s all automatic – stick in the swab and seal it – and it saves interminable transportation routes.“It’s very simple and, with minimum manual work, the doctor gets the result direct, day or night – negative or positive – and can react directly and quickly.”The device can also dferentiate between coronavirus and nine other infections that cause similar symptoms, such as seasonal flu.Its already in use at clinics near Boschs headquarters in Stuttguart and will be made more widely available in Germany next month.There are also plans to distribute the technology - which was created in just six weeks with help from Northern Irish diagnostics company Randox Laboratories - across the rest of Europe.Marc Meier, managing director of Boschs healthcare ision, said: We have succeeded in developing an innovative test in a very short time, which can contribute to curbing the global spread of the coronavirus.The particular quality of the Bosch test is that through its dferential diagnostics doctors can spare themselves the time they would otherwise spend on further testing.The company refused to say how much each test would cost or how many machines it would manufacture. It also failed to specy its tests  positive rate - which means the number of samples that are wrongly identied as containing coronavirus.Boschs Vivalytics device relies on very similar methods to other tests - polymerase chain reactions, also known as molecular photocopying.When a swab is taken from a patient, the strands of genetic material are copied, passed through a detector and compared against other genetic sequences.Germany is carrying out , coronavirus tests a week, which is the equivalent of more than , of the devices operating for  hours a day.In the UK, testing is being carried out at a much lower rate of around , a day.Last week the test numbers topped , but then fell to a low of ,.As of am yesterday, a total of , people have been tested, of which , were confirmed negative and , were confirmed positive.The government has promised that tests for current viral infection, will reach ,.It also announced that it had bought . million antibody tests which can determine whether someone has already had coronavirus.When a person gets infected by the virus, the body starts making specially designed proteins called antibodies to fight the infection.The new finger-prick test looks for these specic antibodies in the blood to determine whether that person is immune.Once the tests are available, NHS staff and key workers - like doctors and nurses - will be prioritised to enable them to go back to work.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: doctors nurses isolation key workers coronavirus frontline
story: Boris Johnson has revealed that he is the first major world leader to test positive for Covid- – and he used his announcement to once again thank the tireless efforts of the UKs frontline key workers.The -year-old PM said: I am working from home, I am self-isolating, and that is entirely the right thing to do.“But be in no doubt that I can continue thanks to the wizardry of modern technology to communicate with all my top team  to lead the national fightback against coronavirus.“I want to thank above all our NHS staff.“It was very moving last night to join the national clap, but it’s not just the NHS, it’s our police, our social care workers, teachers, everybody who works in schools, DWP staff.”Sun Online has been bringing you stories from the frontline fight against the coronavirus each day this week.Here are the latest updates from the nations dedicated key workers.Dr Murray Ellender, , is a London-based GP and co-founder of eConsult.He says: We’ve got some protective equipment, but its still not enough. We’ve been told that within  hours we’ll at least have a plan, so that’s some optimism.But it’s still a worry, how we’re being exposed. In some cases, the protection is not adequate.We had news of the first GP to possibly have died of Covid- today. It’s tragic – we were bound to see it at some point. It won’t be the last case.As this thing grows, we’re going to get more health workers exposed, just like in Italy, because they’re on the front line.It’s very easy to be gloomy and doom-mongering about the pandemic, but overall I have a sense of optimism.We’ve got some tough weeks ahead, we know that, but in the long-term we’ll come through this crisis.General Practice will also have learned some new ways of interacting with patients that will probably make the NHS better in the long term too.Doctors have learned how to do video consultations so hopefully we’ll see less of the queues outside surgeries on a Monday morning.And last night’s applause was great too. It made the hairs stand up on the back of my neck.It feels like the NHS has the support of the nation.Kirsty Gage, , is a childminder from Kettering, Northamptonshire. She lives with partner Lewis and their -month-old son, Tommy.She says: “Yesterday, we spent all day in the garden.I gave the kids cups of water and a paint brush and they did some painting, they played on the bouncy castle and slides, we played Bear Hunt and we had lunch outside.It was actually good fun and they loved it butit gets cold again, it will be harder to keep them happy.I was gutted to hear the Government announcement last night, about help for the self-employed.It’s great that they are paying  per cent of wages for some but I am not entitled to it as I only started last May so I haven’t filed a taxyet.I’m right back to square one. It seems really unfair. There are other ways I can prove my income.I do monthly invoices for parents, we have proof of bank transfers and contracts.I was a teacher for four years so I’ve always paid my dues. It’s really disappointing.I tried applying for Universal Credit but when you try and upload the necessary documents, it crashes because the site is overloaded.I tried ringing and left a message. I managed to talk to the mortgage company and they said we could freeze our mortgage for three months but there would be extra charges and they can’t tell us what they are yet.Now I’m worried that whatever they charge will put us in a trickier position long term.They should have sorted this by now, because it’s more uncertainty for us.I’ve lost £, a month in income and I feel really let down.”Shannon Summerfield, , is a support worker with not-for-profit Dimensions in Cardf. The organisation offers help to those with learning disabilities, autism, challenging behaviour and complex needs. Dimensions currently has support worker positions vacant all over the country and is seeking new recruits.She says: Today we’re going to be doing some more painting with the ladies, lots of activities today.I was out clapping last night – it was quite heart-warming listening to it all. I was outside and there were fireworks going off and pots and pans.We didn’t knowpeople would take it seriously and go out and actually do that. To hear those people clapping was really, really nice.I do feel a lot better than I did at the beginning of the week – I still think the lockdown was the right thing to do.I hope people will stick to what’s being said and what’s being expected of them. People are working very hard for the NHS.I just hope it doesn’t go on too much longer.My mum, a nurse, had some news yesterday – she might be working on a coronavirus ward.She might have to stay in a hotel to keep me and my sister safe. I wasn’t too happy because obviously I can’t see anyone as it is, and my mum is always there.She might be working with people who’ve tested positive and keeping them safe.Because she works shts it might mean I don’t see anyone in my own house for days. It’s quite hard.That’s why I hope people stick to the lockdown rules – so I can have her home sooner with me.Raegan Drew, , is a funeral director for the Co-op Funeralcare in Edinburgh.She says: It was a bit hectic at the start of the week, with all the changes we had to make, but thankfully there’s been no further changes since Monday so it’s quite calm at the moment.We now have all the correct information to pass on to clients, so it’s all fine.If there is a peak on coronavirus deaths, I am confident we can cope. We’re as fully prepared as we can be and none of us really know what’s round the corner.Hopefully the measures Boris Johnson has put in place will help the numbers stay down.The lockdown is being well observed and everyone is being so considerate, phoning aheadthey need to come in, or conducting everything by phone.Yesterday, my colleague Clare had a client bring in a goody bag for her, full of sweets and juice.She said, ‘I know you’ve had some dficult calls to make this week and you’ve been great, so I wanted to give you a little treat.’Clare was quite emotional about it and I thought that was lovely.We’ve had so many clients expressing their appreciation across the board which means a lot.The clap for the NHS, last night, was a really emotional gesture too.I meet a lot of NHS staff in my work and they do an amazing job. It’s great to see people cheering them on.”Peter Booth, , from Leicestershire is a self-employed plumber running his family business GV Booth, with help from his -year-old dad – who manages the company’s office work.He says: “I’m at a boiler swap today. I got here this morning and of course everyone’s at home so there’s absolutely no parking anywhere.I have a lot of kit so I knocked on someone’s door askingI could leave my van on the street for five minutes and block them off.They said, ‘Don’t be silly, we’ll move our car so you can park on our driveway for the day’.They may have offered that in non-pandemic times, but I feel like there’s a true spirit at the moment to help each other.He actually came out in his pyjamas and moved his car for me.The Government announcement got a very mixed response last night. For me, because I have some savings, I’m covered for now.But for a lot of guys, this is going to force them back out and working, it’s a battle between morals and looking after yourself money wise.I’ve got the option – but some people don’t. If you live your le pay packet to pay packet, this is going to be very tough.I’ve got one friend who went self-employed in the middle of last year, so he’s not done a taxyet.Now he’s not working because he’s got a daughter at home – he’s in a real mess.”Gemma Woodall, , works as a primary school teacher in the village of Holme-on-Spalding-Moor in Yorkshire.She says: We only have five kids in today. There’s four members of teaching staff, a head teacher and a cleaner, so we have more staff than children!It’s funny because it’s completely changed our role at school, we’ve become like a community emergency group!We’ve provided dinners for the local elderly, we’ve provided childcare but not an education as such which isn’t normal for us.We obviously know that there will be some families that won’t be doing anything with their kids, which is worrying.Then we also have a nursery attached and a lot of the kids do half days.But now we’ve had the odd child having to do the whole day, as their parents are working extra shts as carers or for the NHS, or they can’t stay with their grandparents anymore.It’s quite a big step for three year olds to go to full days.Our area is now considering setting up hubs of schools, so we’re not all open inidually.There’s also talk of doing that through the Easter holidays with supply staff, so we can all have a break, but nothing’s confirmed.I’m preparing to work from home now from next week, while some other teachers take my place.I was just thinking last night, I’m absolutely knackered.I think it will be good for the children to have another teacher to think of new activities, because I think the novelty will wear off.”Sam Oxley, , is a senior sous chef at Italian restaurant Forza Win, in Peckham, South London. He says: “I won’t lie, since being sent home from work, I’ve felt a bit lost.I’m used to working  plus hour weeks, and being constantly on the go, and now all of a sudden I’m allowed out once a day and have a lot of time on my hands.Like a lot of those unable to work, suddenly I’ve found myself at a loose end, but I’m in a fortunate position and trying to remain positive.I’ve been taking the time out to research new recipes, and have been putting all my efforts into cooking new dishes.I know other people are looking for new ways to stay busy, so I’ve also started to post easy to follow step by step recipes on Instagram so people can try it at homethey like – it’s keeping me busy.I know I can’t complain at all – last night we joined the round of applause for the NHS, and it really put things in perspective.If all I have to do is stay at home to protect the NHS and help save lives, it’s really the least I can do.”Katie*, , is a social worker, supporting vulnerable young adults between -, many of whom have left the care or prison system, and often have severe mental health issues.She says: As a social worker I’m used to working under pressure and dealing with emergency situations calmly and pragmatically, but this week and everything it’s thrown at us has tested even me.It’s so heartbreaking to see the young people I support struggle, as for many of them, le at the best of times is hard enough while they deal with mental health issues and dysal family problems.Now, they’ve had to deal with the added pressures of money worries, social isolation, and the general panic that comes with living in a pandemic.Being in lockdown and isolated is a horrible situation, especially for someone who is very reliant on others for support, which is why I’ve been trying my best to ensure I get in touch with them daily, so they know there’s someone still there.These are testing times, but actually, I’ve also been so touched by people’s willingness to help too – from sourcing a car seat for a newborn baby, to donating money to help us be there for our young people – it’s so nice to know people care.”*Names have been changed to protect identities.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk coronavirus symptoms list too short
story: Experts say that the NHS online symptom checker is too simplistic and could even put people at risk as they may be dismissing milder symptoms.For those who are concerned about having Covid-, the online tool asks whether they have a fever, cough or breathlessness.If the user responds saying they have none of them, they are told: Youre unlikely to have coronavirus.But other governments around the world, as well as private companies, appear to have set up much more thorough online tools.In France, everyone is asked  questions, including whether they have a sore throat, aches and pains, fatigue or a loss of taste and smell.By responding yes to any of these - regardless of whether you have a cough, fever or shortness of breath - people are told to monitor your condition carefully and limit contact with other people.Meanwhile, in the US, citizens have access to a chatbot called Clara, which was created the Centre for Disease Controland Microsoft.It asks userstheyve had a cough, fever, or shortness of breath, before being askedtheyve experienced nausea or diarrhea, fatigue, muscle aches, a headache, a sore throat or a runny nose.Those who answer yes to any of the latter signs are not told whether or not they have Covid- but advised to stay at home and monitor their symptoms.In South Korea, which has been praised for testing every potential coronavirus case, there is also a chatbot tool available to check symptoms.Its accessed through the countrys most popular messaging service KakaoTalk - similar to Whatsapp - and as well as the key symptoms, it also flags other indicators such as a blocked or runny nose, sore throat or diarrhoea.The service says that its list is based on information from the World Health Organisation.It comes as:Experts say that in comparison with the approach taken by other countries, Brits could be at risk as it may leave them less cautious about symptoms.Jonathan Ball, professor of molecular biology at the University of Nottingham, told the : “Throughout the outbreak I have been incredibly bothered by the [UK’s] restricted case definition.“When you look at the medical reports describing how cases are presenting, particularly mild infections, coronavirus patients clearly have cold-like symptoms.Prof Ball added: “Nobody at any other time would try and do a dferential diagnosis for a respiratory virus based on symptoms alone. Yet here we are with a new virus relying on that because we don’t have the capacity to test.”Translated into English, they are:. Do you think you have or have had a fever in the past  hours  . In the past few days, do you have a cough or an increase in your usual cough . In recent days, have you noticed a sharp decrease or loss in your taste or smell . In the past few days, have you had a sore throat and   or muscle pain and   or unusual body aches . In the past  hours, have you had diarrhea  With at least  loose stools.. In recent days, have you been unusually tired . Have you been unable to eat or drink FOR  HOURS OR MORE . In the past  hours, have you noticed an UNUSUAL shortness of breath when speaking or making a small effort . What is your age   This is to calculate a specic risk factor.. What is your size   In order to calculate the body mass index which is a factor influencing the risk of complications of the infection.. What is your weight   In order to calculate the body mass index which is a factor influencing the risk of complications of the infection.. Do you have unbalanced high blood pressure  Or do you have heart or vascular disease  Or are you taking cardiological treatment . Are you diabetic . Have you had or have you had cancer in the past three years . Do you have respiratory disease  Or are you followed by a pulmonologist . Do you have chronic kidney disease on dialysis . Do you have chronic liver disease . Are you pregnant  . Do you have a disease known to lower your immune system . Are you taking immunosuppressive therapy  It is a treatment that lowers your defenses against infection. Here are some examples: corticosteroids, methotrexate, ciclosporin, tacrolimus, azathioprine, cyclophosphamide .. What is your postal code   This information allows us to carry out epidemiological monitoringDr Sarah Jarvis, GP and clinical director of Patientaccess, said: The current NHS checker asks people to self-isolatethey have a fever of . degrees C or higher or a new cough lasting at least half a day.There are other symptoms of coronavirus but these are the most common ones.Other symptoms include headache, feeling generally achy, sore throat and extreme tiredness.In the last week or two, two other possible symptoms have emerged.The first is loss of sense of smell without any obvious reason, such as hay fever.The second is gut issues, including diarrhoea.Currently people aren’t officially required to self-isolatethey have these symptoms without cough or fever.However,you want to be really safe, it is worth considering isolating yourself for at least  days and getting your family to self-isolate - away from you as well as staying inside - for  daysyou have at least one of these other symptoms.Paul Hunter, professor of medicine at the University of East Anglia, pointed out that the NHS online checker was based on a paper published in late February on the clinical characteristics of the coronavirus in China.But he added that the problem for all healthcare providers is that the symptoms are broad and cases can be extremely mild.Public Health England said that the NHS  symptom checker follows the case definition set by the Chief Medical Officer, Professor Chris Witty.Steve Powis, NHS England Chief Executive, speaking at a press briefing, said: “Like many viruses that give infections of the upper respiratory tracts. There is a range of symptoms.The two commonest are by far cough and a fever and that is exactly why they are the two symptoms that we are asking people to self-isolatethey get those symptoms.”The Sun Online has contacted NHS England for comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk property for sale mansion bowling alley
story: The incredible pads are in the top five most viewed homes for sale on Rightmove this year.A mansion with its own staff lodge and a boasting a spa also made the list.If you’re looking for some distraction from current events, then take a look inside these beautul homes.La Baie, a luxurious beachfront property in Sandbanks, Dorset, is tucked away in one of the most exclusive neighbourhoods in the country.La Baie boasts utterly remarkable sea views, has a tree-lined garden with direct beach access, and is just a stone’s throw from several championship-standard golf courses.The magnicent home stands on ‘Britain’s Palm Beach’ – an exclusive peninsula at the mouth of Poole Harbour – with football legend Harry Redknapp among its residents.This property is listed for sale with Lloyds Property Group for £.millionSet in an enormous  acres of beautul parkland in Surrey, there is a sprawling -bedroom mega-mansion has its own private, indoor two-lane bowling alley, complete with disco lighting.The masterful property is approached via a sweeping drive to reveal a colonnade entrance and an iconic Georgian style façade.If that isn’t enough to dazzle your guests, you can entertain friends and family by showing them around your very own tennis court, stables or either one of the indoor or outdoor swimming pools.Youll need to be able to afford the £m price tag though.Sieru House in Surrey is a beautully contemporary family home that has character in abundance. title: eagle carries pig australia pictures
story: Photographer Clarke Espie, , captured the incredible moment when he heard shrieking in the skies above his campsite in the Cromarty Wetlands of Queensland, Australia.Instinctively grabbing his camera, Clarke was shocked to see a piglet screaming as it was carried through the air in the clutches of an enormous sea eagle.The pig was eventually ripped apart and eaten by two of the huge raptor birds.Clarke, an experienced documentary filmmaker, says that while he was in the area to photograph its wildle, he never expected to capture such a breathtaking sight.He said: “Little did I imagine witnessing two massive sea eagles swooping low over my vehicle, one with a feral pig firmly gripped in its powerful talons.“Despite its powerful wings, the sea eagle struggled to gain altitude before landing its prey upon a small island within the wetlands, where together the eagles shared the prey.”Clarke added that it was “one of the most unusual sights I’ve seen.”Describing the moment he saw the eagles, he said: “I thought it must’ve been a fish at first but as soon as I focussed, I could see it was a piglet.“It must have weighed around five kilograms. Definitely not something I’ve witnessed before.”The majestic white-bellied sea eagles – whose wingspan can reach over seven foot - are normally seen perched high in a tree or soaring over waterways and adjacent land around the Aussie coast.Queenslands feral pigs are commonly regarded as a pest as they degrade soil as well as damaging crops and stock.It is estimated that Australia has up to  million of the feral beasts.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann cops cash hunt
story: The Home Office is likely to approve the Met Polices request for extra funds to help continue the investigation into Madeleines disappearance.Funds for Operation Grange - established to probe what happened when the little girl went missing - are set to run out in days.But a source told the Sun Online there will be no problem with new funds being given the green light and the operation will not be axed.A Met Police source said today: There has been some recent speculation that the investigation into Madeleines disappearance could be put on hold or discontinued because of the coronavirus epidemic and a shortage of officers working.This isnt the case and we cant see the outbreak causing a problem for this ongoing inquiry.Neither can the Home Office.Weve been told there will hopefully be no problem with new funding.Madeleines parents Kate and Gerry say theyre buoyed up by Scotland Yards iron will determination to continue with the search for their daughter, who vanished during a family holiday in Portugal nearly  years ago.Through their spokesman Clarence Mitchell, the couple say they are greatly encouraged that officers believe there is active work left to be done.Mr Mitchell said: While an active investigation is ongoing, it gives them hope that one day they will find out what happened to Madeleine after all these years.The Met has an iron will determination to find the answers Kate and Gerry so desperately want.Maddie was just three when she disappeared from a holiday apartment in Praia da Luz in May .Her parents were dining in a nearby tapas restaurant with friends, but were making regular checks on their three children.Heart doctor Gerry, , and former GP Kate, , who live in Rothley, Leics., have never lost hope that their daughter could still be alive.Maddie would now be almost .The Sun Online revealed last month that police had requested extra cash.Detectives put in a formal bid to the Home Office for funding to continue when the current amount runs out on March .A source said: There is still work left to be done on this inquiry and we are anticipating our new funding request will be approved.The operation launched in May  on the orders of then Prime Minister David Cameron.There were concerns it could be shelved because of the demands placed on policing by the coronavirus.Mr Mitchell said the McCanns never take for granted that further funding will be automatically approved.However, he said they have not been advised that the inquiry is coming to an end.Maddies great uncle, retired headteacher Brian Kennedy, has previously told how the family still has hope, even after all these years.The -year-old, who spoke on the th anniversary of the girls disappearance in May , said: Were just grateful that police are still searching. It gives us hope.Officials from the Met Police said today: The Met has previously said that the team leading the investigation into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann is small in number.The team continue to lead that investigation, but can flexit is required.”Representatives from the Home Office have been approached for comment.

title: government coronavirus press conference today friday time

title: jeremy corbyn deluded coronavirus
story: The Labour leader said the Governments massive bailout package for workers and businesses proved he was absolutely right on public sending levels.But opponents said the left-wingers policies would have left the nation broke and unable to cope with such a major challenge.Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith told The Sun: What Jeremy Corbyn said was both arrogant and wrong.If he now believes that, when what we are engaged in at the moment is as a result of this incredible health and economic crisis unprecedented in modern times, then at the last election what he was really offering was a vision of an economically bankrupt country.No wonder the British people sensibly rejected his views.Tory MP Rob Roberts said the outgoing Labour leader was delusional to the end.He fumed: We are taking these extraordinary steps in a time of crisis. You wanted to make them normal.I’m so glad the people saw through your destructive policies at every election you fought. Unbelievable.And fellow Tory MP Alicia Kearns mocked: Corbyn fails to understand even the basics.The Labour leaders claims were also dismissed by leading economists.Julian Jessop from the Institute of Economic Affairs said: As usual, he’s missing the point.The current increase in Government spending is only a temporary stopgap until the emergency health measures can be removed and the market economy rebooted again.In contrast, Labour was proposing a permanent increase in the size and role of the state.The costs of the inidual measures being taken today are still relatively small compared to many of Labour’s proposals. title: birmingham airport morgue coronavirus
story: BIRMINGHAM Airport could be turned into a temporary coronavirus mortuary for , bodies.Police chiefs say the huge mortuary could be expanded to cope with more bodies as the grim death toll today hit more than  fatalities.The West Midlands itself is considered a coronavirus hot-spot with  deaths recorded so far.The airport is next to Birminghams National Exhibition Centre , which has already been discussed as a possible location for a temporary field hospital.It is understood that any airport facility could initially have space for , bodies, increasing to up to ,,needed.Senior Birmingham Coroner Louise Hunt said: We understand that it is a very dficult time for everyone and we will do all that we can to make sure bereaved families understand what is happening to their loved ones and to release them for funeral as soon as we can.It is now anticipated that the new site could ultimately accommodate all deaths across the West Midlands.This means it could handle deaths not related to coronavirus as regional mortuaries may close due to staffing the new facility.A Birmingham Airport spokeswoman said: We have been in discussions with the authorities and we will of course co-operate to find a suitable location and help where we can to support the fight back against this pandemic.Deputy leader of Sandwell Council Wasim Ali said: In reality, we have to prepare for the worst as local councils.Weve seen the numbers of deaths just keep rising. title: harry meghan la before coronavirus lockdown blocked move
story: The couple left their rented home in Vancouver and took a private flight to the US before the border between the two countries closed last week.Harry, Meghan and baby Archie are now said to be living in lockdown close to Hollywood in accordance with the sunshine states coronavirus containment measures.Sources close to Harry told the Sun Online the decision was based on concerns the global coronavirus pandemic left them with a small window of opportunity to move.They said: Everyone knows Harry and Meghan have long been contemplating moving to LA. It ticks a lot of boxes for them.It is close to where Meghans mother lives and for Meghan it is obviously a place of much opportunity in terms of work.It was a really hard call for them. Harry, especially, had grown to love Vancouver Island but when they looked at the logistics of things and how badly the virus is spreading they knewthey wanted to make the move they had to act fast.Both Meghan and Harry remain hugely fond of Vancouver Island and plan tothere a lot.We reported last night how the couple took a private flight to the Los Angeles area before the borders between Canada and the US were shut.A royal insider told the Sun: Harry and Meghan have left Canada now for good.The borders were closing and the flights were stopping. title: coronavirus cases in britain doubling every three to four days gove says
story: CORONAVIRUS cases in Britain are doubling every three to four days, Michael Gove warned this evening.The Cabinet minister updated the nation that the disease is continuing to spread rapidly through the population - and reminded everyone of the need to take lockdown rules seriously.The UKs coronavirus death toll rose by  to  today in the biggest -hour jump so far. , are currently infected in Britain.Mr Gove told the daily Downing Street briefing: The best scientic advice now is that the rate has been doubling every few days.These figures are a powerful reminder of the need for all of us to act.We need to slow the spread of the virus.More work was being done to get the NHS ready for the coming influx of cases in hospitals, he said.This is a united national effort and the spirit of selflessness shown by so many is truly inspiring, he added.More than , people have now been tested for the disease since the outbreak began.Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries revealed that it would likely take weeks for the nation to see the impact of the lockdown, announced on Monday.The cases and deaths are likely to spiral for days to come.She said this evening: We dont expect to see a signicant change in our numbers for two or three weeks.Officials are monitoring the data daily but havent shared any with the public on whether the lockdown is making a dference.This evening NHS chief Simon Stevens told the nation that frontline NHS workers would finally get tested for the deadly bug from this weekend., beds are to be made available for coronavirus patients across the NHS, he added.And he revealed that two more emergency hospitals are on the cards - in Birmingham and Manchester - on top of the London Excel centre which will open next week as NHS Nightingale.It comes just hours after Boris Johnson and Matt Hancock BOTH tested positive for coronavirus today - and Chief Medical Officer Chris Whity has symptoms too.The PM, , was tested after experiencing mild symptoms of a cough and fever yesterday afternoon and will remain in self-isolation in his No flat for at least seven days.Hes believed to be the first world leader to get the virus, and found out his diagnosis late last night.And the Health Secretary, , announced just hours later that he has it too.This afternoon Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty said he has been suffering symptoms too and would self-isolate as a precaution.Its not clearhes being tested too.Both will be working in their homes for the time being.Mr Hancock first developed symptoms on Wednesday after addressing the nation at a press conference on Tuesday alongside Deputy Chief Medical Officer, Jenny Davies, and National Medical Director at NHS England Stephen Powis.The PM wont be doing any of the daily press conferences while he is currently ill.He will have to self-isolate for at least  days from his girlfriend and fiance, Carrie Symonds, , who is currently pregnant - and in the more vulnerable category.Last night she posted a snap of herself and pet dog Dilyn, online saying she was currently self-isolating.Its understood she left No a couple of days ago - and is thought to be in the couples Camberwell flat. commentator Camilla Tominey, a friend of Carries, told ITVs This Morning: Shes in Camberwell with Dilyn the dog so she will not have any contact with the prime minister over the last few days.A Downing Street spokesperson confirmed the news, saying: “After experiencing mild symptoms yesterday, the Prime Minister was tested for coronavirus on the personal advice of England’s Chief Medical Officer, Professor Chris Whitty.“The test was carried out in No  by NHS staff and the result of the test was positive.“In keeping with the guidance, the Prime Minister is self-isolating in Downing Street.At the moment the PM will continue to work, but it may mean that Dominic Raab, the Foreign Secretary, will have to take over dutiesthe PM becomes more ill.As the First Secretary of State he is the second most senior person in Government and technically the PMs deputy.Just yesterday Boris took part in a G call with other leaders around the world to coordinate the international response.No staff will have to stay m from the PM at all times - and will have to drop his meals outside his door.The news comes just weeks after Boris said that he was continuing to shake hands with everyone, despite the risk of the virus spreading.This morning a string of politicians - including Jeremy Corbyn - sent their best wishes to the PM and hoped he had a speedy recovery.The Labour boss said: I wish the Prime Minister a speedy recovery and hope his family are safe and healthy.Coronavirus can and does affect anyone. Everyone be safe. title: coronavirus cat belgium
story: The sick moggy had dficulty breathing and COVID- was detected in its poo, authorities said – making this the first confirmed case of a pet in Europe having the virus.Two dogs in Hong Kong were also struck down by coronavirus after contracting it from humans.In the Belgium case, the woman, who authorities have not identied, lives in the city of Liege, reports the Brussels Times.Steven van Gucht, of the countrys Institute of Health, said “a coronavirus infection has been determined in a cat.”He added: “The cat lived with her owner, who started showing symptoms of the virus a week before the cat did.”Mr Gucht stressed that this is “an isolated case” adding “there are no indications that this is common.”“Additionally, in this case, we are talking about a human-to-animal transmission, not the other way around....The risk of animal-to-human transmission, is very small,” he said.Describing the animals symptoms, he said: “The cat had diarrhoea, kept vomiting and had breathing dficulties. The researchers found the virus in the cats faeces.Belgian health authorities said the pet had “transient respiratory and digestive disorders.”They added that “there is no evidence to date that the virus is being transmitted from pets to humans or other pets.”However, animal owners in the country who believe their beloved beasts may be infected should contact their vets.Infected people are also being urged to limit their time with their pets and to wash their hands before and after touching them.A spokesperson from Belgiums National Council for Animal Protection said: “The transmission was made from person to the cat, not from cat to person.“Lets not go back to a dark medieval period when ignorant people hunt and kill cats for fear that they will pass on the plague.”COVID- has killed a total of  people in Belgium while over , have contracted the bug.In the Hong Kong cases, both dogs contracted the virus from their owners - while the first mutt that caught it died just two days after being released from mandatory quarantine on February .The World Organisation for Animal Health has reiterated that there is no evidence to suggest pets can pass the virus to their owners.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus self isolation parking ticket
story: A MAN in isolation after suffering coronavirus symptoms had to watch as traffic wardens repeatedly ticket his car outside his house despite pleas from his doorstep.Peter Pratt was ticketed four times outside his home in Chatham, Kent, after being sent home from work with symptoms of Covid-.The -year-old would usually collect visitor parking permits from his library because the council had not yet delivered his residents permit.But unable to get hold of the temporary permits, he could only watch on as he was slapped with fines totaling £, despite shouting from his door step that he was in self-isolation.Peter, an appliance tester who was sent home from work last Tuesday, even placed notes on the windscreen explaining his situation.He filmed one incident on his smartphone in order to gather evidence to support his appeal.Peter said: I would normally have been out there swearing at them a lot more than I was.You just think they would use a bit of common sense.I had been trying to keep an eye on it. On the first day, I saw a traffic warden put one on my car, I tried to explain through my window that Im in self-isolation.They just said Oh well, we dont care. We are just here to do our jobs.Peter left his house to collect the tickets on Tuesday and is now appealing all four fines.He said: Im worried about my finances because Im on statutory sick pay and my salary will be cut by  per cent for the next three months.Now Im hoping that the council make the right decision and accept my appeals.Medway Council has now said it will focus on more serious parking offences during the coronavirus crisis.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.A council spokesperson said: We understand that due to the Coronavirusthere may be less parking available on Medways residential roads as more people are at home with their vehicles.However, it is essential that we maintain safe roads and pavements for pedestrians and other motorists.We will be now concentrating our parking enforcement on vehicles which are parked in a dangerous or inconsiderate manner.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meet mr jones very ordinary
story: NewsopinionMeet Mr Jones - the very ordinary man who didnt get coronavirus, but will die from it anywayYou may survive the bug, but we can all get bitten by something even worse, says Fleet Street FoxShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  MAR Newsopinion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis is Mr and Mrs Jones. He is an engineer, she is a florist. They have two children, one car, and a mortgage. He was made redundant from a petrochemical company two years ago. He used the money to set up his own firm, and had a big idea for a pollution-free carburettor. To start with, he worked as a taxi driver to make ends meet. He earned £, that first year. Then he had an idea for a device that would enable people to fry sausages evenly, and sold it to a manufacturer. They gave him £,, so he and his we traded in their -year-old Peugeot for a new estate, putting down a deposit and agreeing a finance deal for the rest. In the past  months Mr Jones has paid his income tax, idend tax, and corporation tax. He has carried on designing his carburettor, drives the taxi at weekends, and has had little other income.In early March, the florist closed because of coronavirus. Mrs Jones was laid off a week before the government announced a furlough scheme which would have got her % of her salary - which was only £,, and part-time, anyway.Mr Jones paid last monthaposs £ mortgage, but has just heard the government wonapost be giving him anything, either. The Chancellor says he canapost be helped, because they donapost know enough about him - even though heaposs paid tax for nearly  years.  Mr Jones is cross. He cannot get through to his bank. He applies online for a mortgage holiday, but has no ideaitaposs even been received.Mr and Mrs Jones isolate when theyaposre told to. She starts home-schooling the children. Mr Jones starts doing shopping deliveries for his neighbours. It costs him £ a week in petrol. They hope for the best, and decide to treat it as quality time with their family.At the end of the month, there is a £ council tax payment. There is a £ car payment. There is a £ electricity bill, which has shot up because theyaposre all at home, and £ water rates to pay. Mr Jones got his mortgage holiday, but no holiday from everything . He decides to pay it all except the credit card, which they had to use during that year he left work and have steadily been paying down. The next month, there is a red credit card bill. Mr Jones cancels the car payment and the council tax. Mrs Jones is trying to make each meal last for two meals, to save money. The children are arguing. Mr Jones spends more time alone, tinkering with his carburettor. Mrs Jones starts to get cross with him.The next month, there are red credit, car and council tax bills. The oldest child racks up a £ phone bill, and Mr Jones hits the roof. He decides to stop delivering shopping to his neighbours. He gets cross when they ask for help, and tells them to bugger off. He and Mrs Jones have lots of arguments about money. She asks him to self-isolate in the spare bedroom. Mrs Jones is told her first mammogram is being cancelled. She does not know it, but it would have caught a small tumour nice and early. It grows, instead. Mr Jonesapos mum, who lives a long way away, becomes ill with coronavirus, then dies. His sister becomes ill, but survives. Her teenage son does not. Mr Jones is not able to go to the funerals, due to the distance and cost of petrol. Mr Jones starts drinking. Now his children are cross with him too. When the government announces the lockdown is over, she takes them to stay with her mum. Mr Jones drinks more. He has started putting the red bills in a cupboard. He doesnapost sleep. His neighbours do not speak to him anymore. But his old employers at the petrochemical company give him a short-term contract. Mrs Jones has her delayed mammogram. The tumour is found, but while before sheaposd have just needed pills now she needs surgery. It makes her re-evaluate things. Afterwards, she trains as a nurse. Thereaposs a shortage, after so many died. Mrs Jones meets a nice man, who doesnapost drink, and isnapost in despair. She goes home to ask her husbandthey can try again. He is bitter and angry, worried about all the things he canapost control. They argue, she says sheaposs met someone but nothingaposs happened, and he hits her. The  call costs £., the trip to hospital £, and police call-out and advice £,.She leaves with two suitcases, and does not come back. Mr Jones cries, and drinks some more. The orce is simple, because she doesnapost want anything and he hasnapost got much anyway. It still costs him £,. The economy recovers, a little. But then the crisis hits a peak in the USA, with , dead. The virus starts spreading through Africa, with the worldaposs supply of raw materials halted. The petrochemical company does not renew Mr Jonesapos contract. Bailfs take the car. The bank which was too busy to talk to Mr Jones when he needed it now calls him twice a day. The local authority want him to tell a magistrate why he didnapost pay his council tax. The phone is cut off, as well as the electricity and the gas. The Jones children do not want to talk to him, but he could not Skype or ring them anyway.  He goes and stands outside the house they are now living in with the nice man. The police call out costs another £,, the legal aid lawyer £, and  hours in custody another £. He accepts a caution.His application for Universal Credit came through. He decides to spend half on food, and half on Scotch, as he does not eat when he is drunk. There is not enough for him to even think about paying the bills.Mr Jones drinks a whole bottle. Then he finds an enormous pile of toilet roll in the garage, which Mrs Jones had bought at the start of the pandemic for reasons which never became clear. In a rage, he sets light to it. The fire engines, ambulance, police, pathologist and coroner investigation cost north of £,. The nice man pays for Mr Jonesapos funeral. The house insurance had lapsed. The insurance company sells the land to a developer, who rebuilds the house. The insurance company and developer make £, in profit.Others do better. A neighbour with a good job begins working from home permanently, and has a better relationship with his children. The teacher next door gets a pay rise in post-pandemic gratitude to public servants, and someone  starts up a new local food delivery business. The area has an uplt in community spirit.But in other areas, thereaposs an uptick in crime. More burglaries, drug problems, street robberies. The police are stretched because thereaposs more domestic abuse, too. The prisons get full. Families get broken. Shoplting is re. There are millions of unemployed.Taxes rise to pay for all the new doctors and nurses, the public pay rises, and the bailouts that were given to businesses. The welfare net stitched together so hurriedly because of coronavirus begins to fray, and lots of people drop through it. This costs us more than helping them.
