title: Rosemary Goring  To see middle-aged children laying down the law to their parents is yet another example of a world gone bananas
story: She hadnrsquot even mentioned that she was intending to go forth and socialise, but they had guessed it was likely. Reluctantly she promised strictly to self-isolate, hence the call to cancel. In some ways I was relieved, because the responsibility had been gnawing at me. Bad enough to fall ill yourself, but a hundred times worseyou pass it on.As last week unfolded, with more stringent government warnings and edicts issued every day ndash sometimes every few hours ndash I heard of more and more instances like this. Children of elderly parents, and some who havenrsquot yet reached retirement age, were imploring, begging, and in some cases emotionally blackmailing them to heed medical advice and stay behind doors.My husband, who is -plus on the outside but at heart still at Newport when Dylan went electric, also came under fire. Hersquod made the mistake of mentioning to his daughter that he had taken a minibus to get groceries. Compared to the -year-old who leapt on a bus to the Buchanan Galleries and bought a piano ahead of the lockdown, hersquod been ultra-cautious. Instead of catching the bus home, he had ed on foot over the hills, his backpack stuffed with goodies.His daughter knew better than to tackle him directly, so texted me instead. ldquoTell her not to worry, he replied. As reassurance goes, it lacked a certain rigour. How often have teenagers told their mum or dad ldquonot to worry when they were neglecting their homework, or spending the small hours who knows where, doing who knows what  Did that lower their blood pressure one iota Up and down the country, the tables have been turned. If this were the era of switchboards, operators could tap into millions of lines and hear the increasingly anxious voices of the middle-aged trying to get their stubborn and defensive old ones to see sense.The problem is, the over-seventies are exceptionally proud of retaining their independence. They bridle at any hint of being past it or not capable of looking after themselves. In normal circumstances this is a healthy mindset, fending off the reality of advancing years and the worry of one day becoming a burden. How many magazine features have you read reporting that  is the new , and weightlting and running are essential to stave off premature rigor mortis  Until the past fortnight, all those who remember rationingand were carrying on asthey were mere striplings were viewed as marvels and inspirations. Now, their gung-ho, can-do spirit has to be put on hold, forced into hibernation for however long this blight lasts. I donrsquot envy any son or daughter reminding their mother or father of their vulnerability, and urging them to take seriously the mortal threat that lies beyond the gate.To see children laying down the law is yet another example of a world gone bananas. You could call it pay-back. Did any of us manage to get through adolescence without coming under constant sniper attack  Most parents griped and girned until their hair turned grey. In our household you could set the clock by the raised voices chivvying us to get out to school, or turn down the radio, or help with the washing up. The small print of parent-child contracts includes the adultrsquos right to scold, ponticate and nag as often as required. Juniorrsquos side of the bargain makes no provision for reasoned argument, protest or rebellion. It states simply that they must unquestioningly obey, preferably for all time.The irony of policing onersquos parents behaviour doesnrsquot make this any easier. But perhaps therersquos a frisson of satisfaction in being able to exact revenge on those who spent the best years of their lives hectoring and carping. Could it feel like a righting of old wrongs to chastise dad for his recklessness, or ask a -year-old to grow up when she suggests an SAS-style dawn-raid on the supermarket It is especially satisfying, surely, that the role reversal necessary to reinforce these new rules is done in the name of commonsense and caring. When the point of the exercise is to protect the lives of those you love, in terms of moral high ground itrsquos up there with Macchu Pichu. What possible riposte can anyone give when urged to take precautions not just to safeguard yourself, but those closest to you Yet as most handbooks to raising a family suggest, nagging is futile. It sets up a vicious circle of resentment and rebellion, and makes the one being chastised feel sore. When people are lectured, they switch off, mentally reaching for the headphones until the tone of voice improves. Whether yoursquore  or , that never changes. So, as a mass technological revolution is rolled-out, with elderly luddites being all but forcibly initiated into the art of video calling, more trouble lies ahead.In an old-fashioned phone conversation, finger-wagging offspring canrsquot see their loved ones rolling their eyes, putting an invisible gun to their temples, or mouthing ldquoGive me a break!. But as soon as they can observe the impact their words are having itrsquoll be like travelling back in time. Theyrsquoll see these beloved faces taking on an unfamiliar juvenile expression: sullen irritation, avoidance of eye contact, nail-biting, fidgeting, a huffily shrugged shoulder.The longer these virus vigilantes bang on, the less response theyrsquoll get. The age-old aria between adult and adolescent is an unequal contest: a torrent of words in one corner, mutinous monosyllables in the other. I donrsquot doubt for a moment that most older folk will pay heed to their familyrsquos concerns. Like any self-respecting teenager, however, theyrsquoll probably pretend not to have heard a word.

title: brian-beacom-future-coronation-street-eastenders-river-city-new-world
story: Angus sighs in agreement. ldquoMental, man. lsquoKeep your distance, but you can board a Glesga train thatrsquos packed tighter than Amberrsquos skinny jeans. You can go out, but yoursquore supposed to stay in. And yoursquoll be in botheryou donrsquot, except you might norsquo cos the polis donrsquot have any real instructionsrsquo.Bob listens: ldquoAnd donrsquot even talk to me about toilet paper, man. That Kimrsquos still using four squares. Pure nightmare.Thatrsquos not a real scene, of course. And it wonrsquot happen, not only because the TV production has now been halted until August.It wonrsquot happen because soap television in Britain never features the real world. It exists to plunder reality from the news stories of the day and reproduce it in open-ended narrative form.And the soap stories, more increasingly, have become huge. The likes of EastEnders and Coronation Street have come to rely upon tales of rape, human trafficking, rail and plane disasters and the occasional arrival of a psychopath to hold viewersrsquo interest.But the problem soap television is facing is it canrsquot come anywhere close to the le wersquore living at the moment.Soaps are written to create clf-hangers. Yet, all our lives are now a personal clf hanger.Yes, continuing dramas have long been a great entertainment form because the characters struggle with le even more than we do.But right now, the only scripts holding our attention are those written by Newsnight or Scotland Today reporters, the narrative provided by newspapers who make some sense of the instruction.Soaps love moral conflict. How can we remain wrapped up in the drama of an Albert Square or a Hollyoaks romance when wersquore being torn apart by huge moral conflicts of our own Do we tell the care workers who look after our dementia-stricken parents not to cross the doorway unless their PPErsquod up to their necks  Do we let our kids go for a second bike ride ndash or kick a ball outside the house Soaps had been a massive part of our lives since they were first introduced in . Wersquove loved Coronation Streetrsquos dank Manchester world of dry sarcasm and humour as dark as puddle water.We loved the fact giant societal changes such as working class mobility were reflected in the tiny lives of the likes of Ken Barlow. We loved the irony in that his social mobility was constrained by his own imagination, and loyalty to a world of HP brown sauce bottles on table tops.Who hasnrsquot worried they will turn into an Audrey Roberts, so desperate for love shersquoll marry a fat councillor and fall for a conman.Yet, as reality TV took audiences away, viewers shrank and soap storylines became gargantuan.They moved away from Ena Sharples mumping about her icose veins and slaying Elsie Tannerrsquos alley cat promiscuity to massive tales of drug gangs and kidnapping.But as storylines have become too big wersquove lost our smugness thatrsquos come from watching others facing unrelenting misery.Yes, there has been a surge in viewing of the likes of Coronation Street and EastEnders this week, with the news episodes are being reduced a visual panic buying by the public.But these are dated storylines, played out by actors BC.And as our reality darkens, soaprsquos attempts to be dark and dangerous will seem a little preposterous.What Corrie and the rest will have to do ndash when filming s ndash is downscale. Go back to the minutiae of peoplersquos lives.Soap has never covered actual reality political parties are forbidden. Celtic and Rangers donrsquot exist in Shieldinch. It canrsquot cover Covid-.But it has toto small stories that reflect the world at large, tell tales using cleverly written metaphors.Wersquore never going to have Bob and Angus debate whether Lenny Murdoch should pay up for a couple of hospital ventilators.But they can talk about the greed of those who could use their money to pay for a homeless shelter in Shieldinch.Giant themes made intimate. That will hold us to a world of escape we sorely need.The soap bubbles have to become smallertheyrsquore still going to wash.

title: neil-mackay-coronavirus-turned-2020-lost-year
story: When we leave our homes, increasingly we see shoppers wearing masks and gloves ndash and therersquos six foot of empty space separating us from the rest of the world or we exercise alone, padding around parks that were once full of children, dogs and their owners, young couples kissing, old couples holding hands. When we speak to loved ones, who live perhaps no further away than the next town, wersquore separated by a screen. Friendship means FaceTime. Distance is now built into love. Most of us are working from home ndash the quiet still of the house, replacing the bustling clatter of the office.The abiding image of , how history will remember this year - will be a lone face at a window staring out onto an empty street. Think of an Edward Hopper painting, an isolated figure in an empty world.Coronavirus has turned this into a year of loss ndash and not just the terrible physical loss thatrsquos death, or the sense of loss that accompanies loneliness. Wersquore losing much of what it means to be alive, to be part of the world wersquore seeing the loss of much that keeps us sane the loss of almost everything that adds colour and iety, nuance and texture ndash and most importantly, meaning ndash to our lives.The hand of Coronavirus has come down like a barrier between humanity and what it means to be human. Wersquore horrically, obsessively, aware of the cold, brutal reality of mass death and the consequences for humanity. We know of the terrible toll the destruction of the economy will leave in its wake. We fear the psychological cost of being separated from those we love.But wersquove not thought deeply enough yet of the price wersquoll pay for the loss ndash the diminution ndash of culture. The economy means jobs and money, and without jobs and money we donrsquot eat, our bodies perish. Without culture, though, and without sport too ndash without these necessary layers of le ndash our souls will starve, just as surely as a humanrsquos soul will starvethey cannot kiss their children, touch their lover, hug their parents.Culture, art, theatre, literature, cinema, music, keeps an interior light burning inside every human for when times are dark. So does sport ndash it lts the human spirit, unites us.I started to feel this great lsquotaking awayrsquo ndash this reduction of my cultural le ndash last week well before lockdown began. And it came in a seemingly unimportant way. The experience was like hearing a distant rumble of thunder and realising a raging storm was approaching.On Monday nights, I get my weekly fix of American political satire when I tune into Last Week Tonight with John Oliver, and then Bill Maherrsquos Real Time show. These programmes are the beating heart of liberal America. Both play before live audiences ndash but not last week. The hosts told their jokes to empty, silent studios. Vibrant, energy-packed stand-up felt hollow, deadened, humourless. And then both shows announced they were going off air.Little spots of light in our culture keep going dark. British TV dramas stopped filming. Release dates for movies were delayed, even the latest James Bond, titled ndash with awful serendipity ndash No Time To Die. Bond may seem inconsequential ndash and, indeed, in the great scheme of things a spy film is utterly meaningless ndash but the mothballing of one of the biggest global entertainment franchises shows just how much Coronavirus has silenced culture.Some will rightly say: therersquos plenty of existing culture to keep us occupied ndash lots of books and films and music. Thatrsquos true, but itrsquos not the point. Thatrsquos not what culture is for. Culture isnrsquot there just to keep you distracted. Culture is also meant to reflect the world wersquore living in, to express the human spirit right here and right now. When culture stops, that canrsquot happen. And eventually, even Netflix will run out of stockpiled programmes. Culture ndash in the shape of books, films and songs ndash is finite. It needs replenished.Writers, musicians and film-makers speak more sincerely to me about the world than any politician. Now those artists are silent, or at least, their latest work is, for the time being, unavailable to help me, and you, navigate our lives.So we arenrsquot just living at a time when culturally our pleasures, our distractions, have been put on hold, wersquore living at a time when culture is most needed yet most absent. This is the year that culturally we stopped, when art, in all its forms, went into suspended animation. No war has ever caused culture to completely cancel. People kept dancing during the Blitz. This cultural silence is new to planet Earth. Itrsquos coronavirusrsquo hateful gt.Of course, wersquoll spring back. Therersquos one facet of human le that hasnrsquot come to a standstill: science, and itrsquos racing forward to save us all.Nor should we forget, that while catastrophes may chloroform culture for a while, culture can never be entirely smothered. And once catastrophes end, culture blooms like a parched garden after rain. The aftermath of the First World War and the Spanish Flu saw modernism flourish, jazz take over the world, the triumph of cinema. After , there was Rock and Roll, and Angry Young Men. The Renaissance was born from the Black Death.In this time of cultural silence, we need to remember the one thing culture has always said loudly: the human spirit is indomitable. The show must go on.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

title: issue-day-baking-bread
story: Itrsquos a staple Bread remains one of Britainrsquos favourite foods, with % of households buying bread ndash around  million loaves are sold each day in the UK. In store bakeries produce about % of bread, with the remainder by local high street bakeries.Variety Over  dferent kinds of bread are produced in the UK, according to the Flour Advisory Bureau , from butter rich brioche and farmhouse loaves, to crisp baguettes and crumpets. Sandwiches account for % of bread consumption whether bought or made-at-home.The best thing since Sliced bread was first introduced into the UK in the s after US inventor, Otto Frederick Rohwedder, created the first slice-and-wrap bread machine in  and sold it in a baker in Michigan. Within five years, of all bread sold in the US was sliced and wrapped and the phrase lsquothe best thing since sliced breadrsquo was born.Panic-buying The pre-lockdown hysteria saw bread become one of the main products to vanish from store shelves, but of course, it doesnrsquot last for long.And so Brits have begun making their own, clearing the supermarket shelves of flour in order to do so, while a visit to the supermarket under allowed lockdown conditions will ironically likely see a fairly well-stocked bread aisle now.But bakers are having a blast and social media timelines are peppered with pictures of freshly baked batches of everything from a simple loaf to artisan breads.Celebrity fans They include US actress Jenna Fischer, who starred in Americas The Office, and the BBCrsquos technology correspondent, Rory Cellan-Jones, who are among those to post daily bread-making updates online.Itrsquos about more than the outcome Bakers are being open about the love of the process and turning to it as a way of soothing the soul.Now FAB - which since  has been providing information on all matters relating to flour and bread in the UK - is working to promote the baking of bread as a way to self-care.Bake to stay sane Thatrsquos what FAB says, simply: "Bake to stay sane during Covid- self-isolation," adding: "As many a Christmas has shown up ndash being cooped up in close proximity with ones family for any extended period of time can have a negative effect on levels of happiness and sanity. Learning to bake, or improving your baking skills is our solution.ldquoIt provides a much required focus gives you the opportunity to set and achieve goals and learn new skills you get to spend quality time with your family and housemates - oryoursquod prefer ndash you get to spend quality time in the kitchen away from your family and housemates! And the icing on the cake ndash you end up with a house that smells amazing and something scrummy to eat.MAUREEN SUGDEN

title: herald-diary-learning-guitar-dont-fret
story: OUR story about a young chap with an eccentric notion of how to learn the piano reminds Martin Black of his failed attempt to master the guitar in his youth. He recalls complaining to his mother that learning the stringed instrument was painful on the fingertips. Mum suggested he wear gloves while playing. ldquoI thought that was daft, Martin recalls, ldquoSo I sarcastically told her I might as well wear mittens. Mum, whose attention wasnrsquot entirely focused on her son, smiled vaguely and said: ldquoYes, dear. Excellent idea.Nose nothingA FEW years ago Rachel Rawle from Pumpherston began dating a posh English bloke. A few weeks later they split up acrimoniously with Rachel saying to her busted beau: ldquoYour nose is like one of those Highland cow-y things. The busted beau was bamboozled.ldquoI was trying to say he was toffee-nosed, Rachel explains. ldquoBut I was so flustered I couldnrsquot think of the correct words. I just kept seeing an image in my mind of the McCowanrsquos Highland Toffee cow.Literally loopyALBERT Uderzo, the French co-creator of comic book character Asterix the Gaul died recently, making Diary contributor John Mulholland rather sad. Though sadness turned to pedantry when he suddenly thought to himself: ldquoAsterix ... the gall of some people who use that word instead of asterisk.Tactless talkThe teacher of acting student Gordon Roper recently told him he wasnrsquot doing very well in mime class. ldquoI was speechless, says Gordon.Shoe-in for prizeRUMMAGING through boxes in the attic, Sheila Munro from Shawlands discovered an old diary she kept when she was eight-years-old. Flicking through the pages to seethere was any hint of genius in her younger self, she soon found definitive proof. ldquoLearned to tie shoe-laces, was the diary entry that filled her with pride and made her wonder why shersquod never won a Nobel Prize for being a Smarty-pants. The next dayrsquos entry took the swish out of her swagger. ldquoForgot how to tie shoelaces, was written on the page.Wooden woesTWENTY years ago Steven Collins scratched his name and that of his girlfriend on a park tree. Now married, the couple ed to look at the tree recently and were disappointed to discover it gone. A park gardener informed them all the trees in that area had been chopped down a few years before, and put on a bonfire. ldquoI guess thatrsquos what Elvis meant by burning love, sighs Steven.Pedestrian parentDAFT joke of the day. ldquoWhat do you call a father without a car  asks reader Terry Essex. The answer is, of course: ldquoThe walking dad.

title: uzma-mir-stay-go-love-time-lockdown
story: The following weekend you find yourself being rushed alone into a taxi of shame by your new potential love interest after having over-indulged in the Cosmopolitans, after a night out, clubbing. You are worried that the Cosmos might have put him her off but, by a marvellous stroke of luck, the following weekend is Valentines weekend, and love is well and truly in the air. Your dodgy behaviour is forgotten amidst cards, heart-shaped chocolates and flowers. There might even have been a kisshellip.or two.A month after that first meeting you are going for windswept walks up hills, and enjoying long, lingering romantic meals, as you gradually get to know your new squeeze. Ah sweet, romantic bliss.Cut to six short weeks later and lovely beau is screaming down the phone: ldquoAre you in or out  Are you self isolating with me or not  Decide NOW, before they start fining us for a bit of nookie!This is the sweaty-palm inducing choice facing a few friends in relatively new relationships. In fact, so important is this issue that the deputy chief medical officer for England, Jenner Harries, mentioned it in a Government press briefing on Tuesday this week. She said couples living separately should stay separate or ldquotest the strength of their relationship and move in together and that this would be ldquofor quite a signicant period going forward.Signicant period  How long are we talking  A few weeks, a few months, longer  I mean, in a few weeks, as certain lsquounknownsrsquo become lsquoknownrsquo, you might want to gather those heart-shaped chocolates and flowers, and run for the hills. . Your reasons for doing so might include your new partnerrsquos snoring, slurping or sloppy-eating. In a few months yoursquore talking about skin or nose-picking, knuckle-cracking or indulging in well-dodgy un-PC humour. Any longer and you could be facing toenail clippings in the carpet, spot-squeezing and weeing in the shower. But, think carefully ndash you canrsquot leg it because you will be in danger of contaminating another householdyouhome.For some, itrsquos not worth the risk, and I know of at least two couples whorsquove had a good look at one another and thought Covid- could well be the end of their fledgling relationships. ldquoLetrsquos take things slowly, overnight became ldquoletrsquos do it ALL now, and that was a step too far. They favoured the dating, the dressing up, the romance, the excitement of a new lover over the waking up two inches away from a face full of spots, and questionable morning breath, every day. They prefer their splendid isolation to a conscious coupling. I imagine that the % rise in demand for sex toys was these more cautious types thinking ahead to the need for ldquorelief supplies. Irsquom not sure anyone has told them that the wee rabbit thing doesnrsquot constitute an essential delivery, though.For others the upside far outweighs the risk. I see Love Islandrsquos Finley Tapp drove from Milton Keynes to West Lothian to self-isolate with his new girlfriend Paige Turley as soon as Boris told us we were to stay put for the foreseeable, and a friendrsquos son slipped clandestinely out of their house after the broadcast, saying it would be lsquomore funrsquo at his girlfriends. When I was aghast and upset on my friendrsquos behalf, my teenager replied flatly: ldquoEh, what -year-old guy wouldnrsquot want to self isolate at his hot -year-old girlfriends, rather than his mums  But I know hersquos still taking revenge for the fact I spray him with disinfectant whenever he comes in the house.So lockdown love can clearly go one way or the other, but what it does do is shine a light on some big philosophical questions like who we are, whatrsquos important to us, how we interact with those close to us and, most of all, where nookie stands in our list of priorities.

title: coronavirus-cases-global-pandemic-set-exceed-500-000
story: Italy and the United States appear poised to surpass China, where the pandemic began, while healthcare systems in Europe and New York buckle under the weight of caring for seriously ill victims of Covid-.Spain has become the country in Europe where the outbreak is spreading the fastest. Spainrsquos Health Ministry reported , new infections and  deaths yesterday, bringing the total cases to , and more than , fatalities, second only to Italyrsquos death toll of ,.:Fears of surge in poverty as economy hitThe Italian region worst hit by coronavirus has seen a steep decline in the number of deaths and infections but fears are growing that the countryrsquos south could become the next hotspot.Recent numbers from the northern region of Lombardy suggested the epidemic might be slowing at its epicentre.But poorer southern parts are seeing a sharp rise in deaths, raising fears the health service could be overwhelmed.Worrying signs are coming from regions such as Campania around Naples and Romersquos Lazio where the health system is considered much less equipped than in the rich north.So far there have been  deaths in Campania and  in Lazio.Faced with the exponential spread of the pandemic, the US Senate has passed a . trillion dollareconomic rescue package steering aid to businesses, workers and healthcare systems.Millions of Americans hoped the measure would give them a leline as they lost jobs, income and childcare due to the social-distancing rules needed to slow the spread of the virus.At least . billion people are now under severe travel restrictions.But the head of the World Health Organisation, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, criticised world leaders for wasting time in the fight against the virus that has already killed more than , people, left millions out of work and ravaged the world economy.He said: ldquo The time to act was actually more than a month ago or two months ago. We squandered the first window of opportunity - this is a second opportunity which we should not squander and do everything to suppress and control this virus.In the United States, where virus deaths passed , and some , people were infected, a fierce political battle raged between those demanding urgent action for a months-long siege against the pandemic, like New York governor Andrew Cuomo, and President Donald Trump.Mr Trump has expressed hope churches couldto normal by Easter, only  days away, and grumbled that ldquoour country wasnrsquot built to be shut down , apparently concerned that the outbreakrsquos devastating effects on financial markets and employment will harm his re-election chances.Democrats say Mr Trump is prioritising the economy over the health and safety of Americans.Joe Biden, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination, said: ldquoIrsquod like to say, letrsquos get back to work next Friday. Thatrsquod be wonderful. But it canrsquot be arbitrary.In Italy, doctors and nurses have been begging the government to provide more masks, gloves and goggles and urged the public to understand how important social distancing measures are. Scientists say stopping just one person from getting the virus means scores of others will not become infected down the road.:Health board denies do not resuscitate policy on Covid- patientsEuropean Union leaders are convening for their third summit in three weeks as they battle to contain the spread of coronavirus and manage the havoc the disease is wreaking on their  economies.As the number of deaths in Europe soared over ,, Spain prolonged a state of emergency that will allow it to impose broader lockdowns while French President Emmanuel Macron launched ldquoOperation Resilience, a military-backed response to combat the pandemic.France began evacuating infected citizens from the hotspot of Alsace using a special high-speed train that its health minister called a ldquofirst in Europe. Around  patients were being taken from Strasbourg to hospitals in the Pays-de-la-Loire and other regions.

story: Sales of fiction rose by a third, while childrenrsquos education went up  per cent to the third highest level on record.Puzzle books, handicrafts and true crime also saw sharp rises.:Cineworld U-turn on staff lay-offsldquoThe sales data suggests that the UK population has indeed been preparing for long periods of isolation, said Nin Book, which keeps track.ldquoWersquove seen signicant jumps in sales of puzzle books, adult colouring titles, home-learning titles for children, study guides, and we have seen been a big increase in sales of paperback novels.The rise for paperbacks may have been down to an increased footfall in supermarkets, Nin said.But physical book sales may now plummet after the public were told only to shop for essentials when necessary. are stuck at home.Illustrator Oliver Jeffers is doing a daily #StayAtHomeStoryTime on Instagram.More than  free Sesame Street ebooks are available ndash along with virtual Elmo hugs and other resources from the childrenrsquos show.Meanwhile, people staying at home due to the coronavirus pandemic appear to be listening to more radio rather than music apps, figures suggest.Global, which owns Capital FM and talk station LBC, said online radio listening had risen by %.The BBC said streaming of its radio stations had risen % since last week.And data from two US analytics companies suggested use of music-streaming apps such as Spoty had dipped by about %.ldquoThese figures indicate that the public are turning to radio in times of crisis, a Global spokeswoman said.BBC Radio and Education director James Purnell said: ldquoPeople turn to us during signicant events for our news and analysis but also for music, entertainment and companionship.ldquoLast week, we saw record live listening on BBC Sounds.The numbers shared by the BBC and Global are from their own online streaming s.Radio Joint Audience Research , the official organisation that measures radio listening figures in the UK, has not released its latest numbers yet.According to trusted music industry monitor BuzzAngle, US music streaming between March  and March  fell by .% compared with the previous week.Rolling Stone magazine, which uses a dferent data provider, Alpha Data, said streams were down .%.:Cases of global pandemic set to exceed ,ldquoThere are likely to be multiple causes, said BBC News music reporter Mark Savage.ldquoFewer people are commuting to work or going to the gym and shops that use Spoty for their in-store music are closing their doors.ldquoPeople who stream music in the office also seem to be turning off and watching Netflix instead and therersquos a big rise in radio listening ndash suggesting wersquore seeking companionship alongside our music.

title: coronavirus-scotland-coping-anxiety-pandemic
story: The financial collapse was well under way. Once in a letime catastrophe, everyone said.Irsquod been covering the story since mid-August when the first danger signals started flashing at American mortgage lenders and a couple of the smaller banks. For months Irsquod been waking up early to write a stock market update for the Globe and Mail and then talking to hundreds of analysts and experts about what might happen next.:Cases of global pandemic set to exceed ,It wasnrsquot that dferent from the coronavirus world wersquore living in now ndash the loudest voices of doom were the most frequently quoted. They said economies would surely collapse around the world, civil unrest would lead to hundreds of thousands of deaths, wersquod lose our jobs and our houses. We may not even get other jobs. Neither would our children.There were nights Irsquod stare at the ceiling and wonder what it would be like to move into my in-lawsrsquo basement with a new baby when things finally turned really bad. It wasnrsquot an optimistic thought process.Irsquod fall asleep and then do the day all over again. Day after day. After day. After day. Week after week.I wasnrsquot unique ndash anyone paying attention faced the same pressures. Autoworkers were losing jobs by the thousands, retailers were closing, the world economy was shedding millions of jobs.Wersquod break records every day ndash declining retail sales, manufacturing indexes, etc. Wersquod then treat the moment with awe as we grasped for any signal that told us things had finally hit bottom and we could start looking forward to a slow turnaround.There werenrsquot any signs that I was pushing myself too far,you donrsquot count chest pains, lack of sleep and dizziness. Then one day I was walking down Bloor Street West with some friends and I felt like I was going to die. I just wanted to run. Or sit. Or walk more slowly. Or spin around in circles. Or something. Anything.I made it home and settled down. It took a while. I went to a doctor shortly afterwards. Irsquove beenmedicated ever since. Itrsquos been years since I felt that tightness in my chest. But yesterday standing in line at the pharmacy ndash outside in the rain for an hour ndash to get a refill on my prescription I felt a little contraction.It got a bit tighter when they told me they could only fill half my order until they received more stock.And then another little squeeze when I opened the box and the order was made up of pills from two dferent manufacturers, rapidly shoved together into a box to get me on my way. I could see the scissor marks on the packaging.Irsquod never seen that before. Or empty shelves in grocery stores, for that matter.The next -hours werenrsquot great. I started refreshing browser tabs too often and paying attention to accounts that were pushing Mad Maxnarratives.I was googling home Covid- tests, reading through migration laws to find outI could be sent homeI became seriously sick and what would happenI died hooked up to a ventilator thousands of miles from Canada with my immigrant family stranded in Glasgow.Thatrsquos called catastrophizing ndash letting your brain trick you into thinking the worst outcome is the most logical. Itrsquos awful. And itrsquos common. I kept it up most of the day, pretending it wasnrsquot stress and I was doing great.When I visited Asda and wanted to cry because there werenrsquot any chicken fajita kits in the meat aisle, I finally took a breath and reminded myself that I knew better. Irsquod been here before. We all have.This is a mess. The economy is a mess. Government bailout programs arenrsquot a mess yet, but they probably will be when itrsquos time to start unwinding all the stimulus and rev up all of the businesses we throttled to stop the spread of the disease. Wersquoll all feel the echoes of this crisis for decades to come.But I canrsquot control any of those things. I can take care of my family. I can check in on my friends. I can do my job well and try to help everyone I work with do theirs well. I can remind people that things always get better.:Book sales up as people self-isolate with a good readAlways. Prove me wrong.I didnrsquot get all the way to a panic attack yesterday ndash I made it home and the dog sat on my lap. I jumped onto a video call with some colleagues and within minutes the tightness was easing. Irsquom lucky to have such great colleagues.I had almost forgotten the lessons I learned through the  recession: the worst-case scenario isnrsquot the most-likely scenario, everyone pulls together in the end, things get better, help is thereyou ask. .I donrsquot know how this all ends. Nobody does. But Irsquom comforted by the lessons of the past. Bad times pass, but the good discovered through crises lingers. Wersquoll get through this ndash we always do.Steve Ladurantaye is the head of news and current affairs at STV

title: sir-tom-hunter-inspires-young-entrepreneur-reach-stars-orbit-programme
story: SOCIAL entrepreneur Kieran Aitken didnrsquot particularly enjoy school. But now, every day is a school day: as the founder and managing director of the teenage incubator programme, Orbit Enterprise Education, ramps up the  to help young people launch their own business.At , his young shoulders carry far more experience that someone of his age would usually have and he tracks his own illustrious career to date like a seasoned entrepreneur on stage at a motivational business conference.Indeed, Aitken credits businessman Sir Tom Hunter, chief executive of The Hunter Foundation and one of Scotlandrsquos most highly regarded philanthropists and entrepreneurs, as a role model and mentor. Recalling their first meeting, he says: ldquoI had the idea for Orbit and heard that Sir Tom was going to be visiting Boyd Tunnockrsquos factory in Uddingston, he says.ldquoIrsquod taken the day off school and waited in the car park, then caught him as he came out ndash it was May , , a date that will forever stick in my mind.Fortunately, Sir Tom took the time to chat to the ambitious young schoolboy.ldquoHe was surprised but receptive, and I think he liked my spark and the fact Irsquod gone out to make something happen, suggests Aitken.Since launching Orbit Enterprise Education five years ago, the business has supported over  students aged between  and  to launch their own businesses- through what Aitken claims is one of the worldrsquos first business incubator programmes for students.Support has come from RBS and Entrepreneurial Spark among others. In , he won pound, in the final of Scottish EDGE ndash the competition aimed at identying and supporting Scotlandrsquos up-and-coming, high-growth potential entrepreneurial talent.From its early roots in Glasgow -with the first two intakes creating  new businesses with an annualised combined turnover of over pound, just four months after the programmersquos launch- Orbit has established ldquochapters in major cities across the UK, including Edinburgh, Birmingham, London and Manchester.Kieran Aitken dropped out of university to focus on building his own business empireOrbit has decentralised its structure and now entrepreneurs based overseas can apply for a licence to run the programme. The organisation, meanwhile, has plans to open chapters in Australia, Canada and the USA by .The incubator programme is a powerful one, suggests Aitken. ldquoWe cover everything that you need to help you be successful in business, he explains.ldquoFrom generating ideas, all the financial and legal stuff like tax and accounts to raising finance and sales and marketing ndash itrsquos very, very comprehensive.ldquoWe provide mentoring and access to leading business figures, advice on how to scale up and grow a business, how to build and lead your team ndash everything that will help create the winning mindset and knowledge required to run a successful business.That said, no amount of teaching, coaching and mentoring can prepare a young person for the hard work and determination required in setting up and running a business. ldquoI think some people have that entrepreneurial gene, says Aitken, who launched his first business at the age of .ldquoFrom quite a young age I wanted to make money and at school I was selling lsquoanything legalrsquo in the playground, he continues. ldquoI was never very academic at school but was an avid reader of business books and started a car and van detailing company with just pound. By the time I was  it was generating a healthy five-figure net profit annually.All the same, the Renfrewshire schoolboy went on to study business at the University of Strathclyde.ldquoIt wasnrsquot a case of not enjoying university, but I was still running my business and not devoting enough time to study so I dropped out in third year, he says. ldquoContinuing wouldnrsquot have been fair on my tutors or myself.Today, he explains, many of his ldquoOrbiteers have the same outlook in that they donrsquot necessarily feel that further education is the best career option for them.ldquoA lot of young people donrsquot know what they want to do, but go to university without any clear goals, says Aitken.ldquoSchool just doesnrsquot work for everyone andthere are problems at home or other issues then that can impact on their studies ndash and for others, the prospect of another three or four years of studying after leaving school isnrsquot attractive.ldquoA good brain and personal drive ndash and the determination to make your own path in le ndash can be worth much more than a degree, he says.ldquoFrom coffee shops to online magazines, wersquove helped young people with bright ideas in many dferent business sectors launch their own companies with some achieving a five-figure income before their th birthday.But Aitkenrsquos message to all young people starting out in business is to ldquonot get carried away too soon.ldquoI moved too quickly on a flawed revenue model and didnrsquot plan very well, he admits. ldquoWe bounced back and are much more careful now and take advice, but it taught me that you canrsquot run a business without making mistakes.ldquoWhen you do make a mistake, donrsquot give up ndash pick yourself back up, get on with it and yoursquoll come back stronger.Orbitrsquos three-month incubator programme, believes Aitken, is the ldquoultimate training experience for the entrepreneurs of tomorrow.To date,  new businesses have been created with Orbitrsquos support and on average there are  applications for every space available on the programme.In addition to running Orbit Enterprise Education as a social enterprise, Kieran Aitken operates DripDrab, a tech business he launched last year that provides card payment processing to tradespeople and allows households across the UK to book a window cleaner at the click of a button.The business is growing at pace and there are plans to expand the  to incorporate additional services such as plumbing and dog walking.Find out more at www.orbit-incubator and www.dripdrab

title: glasgow-artist-colours-blues-away-social-isolation
story: OVER the coming weeks, we are all likely to struggle with the boredom of being stuck at home.Butyou find yourself twiddling your thumbs ndash or climbing the walls - then adult colouring could be the answer.No longer just a pastime of kids trying to stay between the lines, intricate grown-up colouring books have been proven to reduce stress and anxiety, improve motor skills and even aid sleep.In our current hyper-anxious world, adult colouring appears like the perfect solution. The problem is that plenty of us seem to have had the same idea, creating a colouring book shortage that has left them almost as in-demand as loo roll and soap.But all is not lost. In the spirit of community and generosity, freelance graphic designer Claudine OrsquoSullivan has created a free downloadable colouring book that can either be printed out or filled in electronically on a tablet.Naming the project #colourforcalm, Claudine has designed seven dferent illustrations: a tiger, a bird, a cityscape, a gorilla, a jellyfish, a lion and a rhino.She explained: ldquoItrsquos looking like a tough few months for everyone everywhere with the current coronavirus pandemic.ldquoTo curb my own anxiety about the whole thing, Irsquove launched a little personal project to try help those in isolation, socially distancing, feeling anxious or looking for some extra entertainment for the kids.ldquoDrawing has always been an incredibly calming escape for me mentally and I believe it can provide the same for others.ldquoIrsquove designed this for all ages and comfort levels. For those looking for some guidance continue on from my taster using either suggested palette, or your own. Or freestyle it completely! Therersquos no wrong outcomes.The free designs can be accessed at www.claudineosullivan shop colour-for-calm

title: us-coronavirus-cases-world
story: Italy, another of the worldrsquos hardest-hit countries, has closed most of its industry, while masses of Indian day labourers received food rations after a lockdown put them out of work.Increases in the number of cases had been expected as testing becomes more available.:Coronavirus in Scotland: Scottish death toll rises to The US passed China with more than , cases, and Italy also exceeded ,, with the three countries accounting for almost half of the worldrsquos infections from the virus.Most of Chinarsquos patients have recovered, while places where the virus arrived later are now dealing with overwhelmed hospitals and supply shortages and are rushing to convert public spaces for treating the sick.Washington DC confirmed  new cases on Thursday, raising its total to .The district is under a state of emergency, with major attractions like the Smithsonian museums and National Zoo closed, and White House and Capitol tours cancelled.Police have blocked off streets and bridges to prevent crowds arriving to see Washingtonrsquos blooming cherry blossom trees.The stay-at-home order for Indiarsquos . billion people threw out of work the backbone of the nationrsquos economy ndash rickshaw drivers, fruit sellers, cleaners and others who buy food from whatever they can earn in a day.The Indian government announced a . trillion rupeeeconomic stimulus package to deliver monthly rations to  million people. In some places, people received rice rations from police, and aid groups are working to expand their reach.:Boris Johnson tests positive for coronavirusDeaths from Covid- have surpassed ,, more than a third of them in Italy, according to a Johns Hopkins University tally. The US had about , deaths, almost a quarter of them in New York City, where hospitals are overwhelmed.In China, where the virus was first believed to have jumped from wild animals to humans, the National Health Commission reported  new cases, including  it said were imported infections in recent arrivals from overseas.Again there were no new cases reported in Wuhan, the provincial capital where coronavirus emerged in December. China is barring most foreigners from entering as it tries to curb imported cases.The economic damage of the pandemic is growing. Italy has closed down most of its industry, and a record-breaking . million Americans applied for unemployment benefits in a single week.Companies in Europe are laying off workers at the fastest pace since , according to surveys of business managers, and the US is bleeding jobs as well, with numbers applying for unemployment benefits last week ndash . million ndash nearly five times the previous record, set in .You may catch #COVID and be at risk of becoming severely ill,youve a noncommunicable disease a pre-existing condition such as:##Cardiovascular disease##Chronic respiratory disease##Diabetes##CancerFollow the advice from WHO # https:t.co bxRdTRFz #coronavirus pic ThEpLlLJvmdash World Health Organization March , Wall Street rallied for the third straight day after an unprecedented . trillion dollareconomic rescue package to help businesses, hospitals and ordinary Americans pull through the crisis won passage in the Senate. The rescue plan, expected to be voted on in Congress on Friday, would dispense cheques of , dollarsper adult and  dollarsper child.New York statersquos death toll jumped by  in one day, pushing the number to . Governor Andrew Cuomo added that the number will increase as critically ill patients who have been on ventilators for several days succumb. Mr Cuomo said: ldquoThat is a situation where people just deteriorate over time.South Africa, with the most industrialised economy in Africa, began a three-week lockdown on Friday. The country is already in recession, with an unemployment rate of %.Saudi Arabia is locking down the capital Riyadh and Islamrsquos two holiest cities, Mecca and Medina, in addition to a nationwide curfew. In the United Arab Emirates, authorities announced an overnight weekend lockdown and used drones to tell people to stay home.We are going to fight every way we can to save every le that we can.Thatrsquos what it means to be an American and thatrsquos what it means to be a New Yorker. pic cREWGxtmdash Andrew CuomoMarch , The leaders of the G major industrialised nations met in a video summit and vowed to work together to confront the crisis but made no specic commitments.In Brazil, the countryrsquos governors are defying President Jair Bolsonaro over his call to reopen schools and businesses, dismissing his argument that the ldquocure of widespread shutdowns is worse than the disease.As of Thursday, the country had more than , cases and  deaths.In Singapore, penalties are being issued for people who refuse to adhere to social distancing in the latest bid to curb the virus.Anyone not maintaining a distance of one metre from another person in a public place such as a shopping centre can be jailed for up to six months or fined up to , Singapore dollars , or both.

title: coronavirus-scotland-tunnocks-halts-production-amid-pandemic
story: The confectionary firm, famous for their teacakes and caramel wafers, has stopped manufacturing and closed their factory in Uddingston, South Lanarkshire.The company made the move, after considering every alternative, to protect their  staff against the spread of Covid- and allow them to self-isolate.:Chef brings cut-price cuisine to self-isolating Edinburgh localsTunnockrsquos is hoping to recommence production as soon as possible.Director Fergus Loudon said the closure will be reviewed at Easter."We will cease all production and remain closed and review at Easter following government guidelines."Be assured we have considered every alternative but we firmly believe that closure is the only responsible course of action as things stand.:People face pound fines for ignoring social distancing rules"As soon as it is safe to do so we will resume production."We ask for your understanding during what is a very dficult time for us all."Stay safe."

title: michelin-tyre-production-scottish-site-ends-50-years-says-unite
story: The tyre factory, which first opened in , announced in  that it would officially close its doors in June this year.Michelin had initially planned to restart production after April  and carry on until the plantrsquos closure, however the company has concludedit would be ldquounviable and unwise amid the ldquogrowing challenges caused by the coronavirus outbreak.But the timeline has been accelerated in light of the Covid- pandemic, says the union Unite.The closure decision was blamed on an "influx of cheap foreign imports"from Asia into the European market and falling demand for premium tyres in smaller dimensions, according to the union.But the company has said the workforce will be paid thewages they would have been entitled toproduction had ended in the summer.Last year it emerged that  employees hadfound new jobs since Michelin announced the closure of the factory, which opened in .Unite has said it continuesto engage with the Michelin-Scotland Alliance which is working towards the transformation of the site through the development of an Innovation Parc.The initiative aims to create opportunities in manufacturing, remanufacturing, recycling and low carbon transport.Bob MacGregor, Unite regional industrial officer, said: "Its a very sad day for the people of Dundee that  years of tyre production at the Michelin plant has come to an end before the summer when it was scheduled to finish."However, we want to recognise that Michelin has acted as a responsible employer throughout the Covid- pandemic and has agreed to pay the workers their full wages up until the summer. Unite continues to work with the company to find a long-term future through the repurposing of the plant. As one chapter comes to an end, we hope that another one will begin and hundreds of jobs can be retained on site."Factory manager John Reid said employees would be mobilised to volunteer for projects set up by the community, government and health services to support people during the Covid- crisis.ldquoOur priority remains the safety of our workforce. This is an unexpected end to tyre production at our factory, but we believe this is the best decision for our employees and their families.ldquoWe will be developing a new employability programme to help people find their next positive destination, be that retirement, further education or a new job.ldquoWersquore also conscious that some people will find being confined to their homes tough, so wellbeing support will continue to be important.ldquoWe will be using technology and social media combined with a limited presence on site until the virus allows more normal working.ldquoWe would like to take this opportunity to thank our team in Dundee for their support and hard work during what has been a very challenging time.

title: covid-19-symptoms-develop
story: But what are the symptoms of Covid- and can they get worse over time ndash What symptoms do most people experience According to the World Health Organisation , most people infected with Covid- will develop mild to moderate symptoms and recover without requiring special treatment.:Coronavirus in Scotland: How the daily death rate has hit a new highCommon symptoms of the respiratory disease include a fever ndash which NHS England says is usually a temperature of C or above ndash tiredness and a dry cough.ndash Could there be other symptoms The WHO says other symptoms can include shortness of breath, aches and pains, and a sore throat.Some people have also reported a loss of taste and or smell, as well as abdominal pains.ndash When do symptoms begin to show and can they get worse Chief medical officer Professor Chris Whitty said that it takes about five days from getting Covid- for symptoms to show, and then up to a week to recover.Those who get more seriously ill tend to do so after about five or six days of having the illness, he added.Therersquos lots of scary misinformation out there mdash keep yourself and your loved ones safe by getting your information from a trusted source. Visit https:t.co ZYYFNxwJXf to learn about symptoms of #coronavirus, what you should doyou have them, and how to prevent the spread.mdash NHS England and NHS ImprovementMarch , ndash Can I get Covid- and not experience any symptoms According to the WHO, some people become infected but do not develop any symptoms and do not feel unwell.ndash Who is most at risk Those with an underlying medical condition and people over the age of  have a higher risk of developing severe symptoms.The WHO says that around one out of every six people who gets Covid- becomes seriously ill and develops dficulty breathing.

title: edinburgh-festival-fringe-organisers-give-definitive-answers-2020-event
story: Partners have been holding talks about the arts festival taking place in August amid safety fears around the Covid- pandemic.Many large-scale events ndash such as Euro  ndash have already been delayed due to the coronavirus outbreak.Fringe Society chief executive Shona McCarthy said: ldquoIrsquom grateful to the hundreds of artists, producers, venues, residents and audience members who have been in touch with us this week to share their thoughts on the future of this yearrsquos Fringe.ldquoWhilst there have been many dferent opinions expressed, we know that definitive answers are needed and we hope to have them for you next week.ldquoProgress is being made in this area and we will continue to push for answers over the coming days.She added: ldquoThis week we have been in regular dialogue with Scottish Government, City of Edinburgh Council, venues, partners and other stakeholders to work through all the options and find solutions.ldquoThis is a complicated process but one that is moving forward daily.ldquoI appreciate that the delay is frustrating but I promise we will do everything we can to update you as soon as possible over the coming days.ldquoIn the meantime, please keep talking to us.

story: The five star Balmoral Hotel which opened  years ago in , has wooden boards covering ground floor windowsand glass  in the front door of the grand entrance.The Victorian hotel, owned by Sir Rocco Forte, has joined other businesses taking safety measures.Another iconic hotel, The Waldorf Astoria Edinburgh ndash The Caledonian also closed its doors for the first time since its opening in .Managers of the Balmoral, with the famous number  Princes Street address, has so far not commented on the need to board the the landmark building up.In case anyone doesnrsquot realise the severity of the current situation, one of the worldrsquos most iconic hotels, the Balmoral Hotel, is closed and boarded up. pic fRAIgumLicHe said the hotel would reopen its doors "even more proudly" when the time came.The hotel which overlooks Waverley Station in Edinburgh, has welcomed guests including Laurel and Hardy, JK Rowling, Elizabeth Taylor, Paul McCartney and the Queen Mother since it opened in .

title: bureaucrats-halt-emergency-release-coronavirus-hand-sanitiser
story: HMRC has relaxed licensing rulesso drinks firms can produce sanitiser for use in hospitals and other critical facilities.But Moray Council Trading Standards has allegedly stopped a gin company in Speyside from rushing out its vital, alcohol-based cleanser - and is believed to have been the first council in Scotland to do so."Its bureaucracy gone mad," said the gin companys owner, who did not want us to release her name or identy her company.She added: "My hands have been tied up in red tape."Our first batch was due to go out free and thereafter wed only chargewhatever the ingredients cost us."Theres no profit being made.HMRCs relaxation of the licensing rules allows distillers to make sanitiser based on a recipe set out by the World Health Organisation.: Donald Trump wishes Boris Johnson a "speedy recovery" from the coronavirusCompanies across Scotland and the UK are now hard at work producing the anti-bacterial gel, which is running in short supply due to huge demand.The Speyside gin firm made a large amount of sanitiser but was shocked when Trading Standards asked to analyse a sample and check the label - even examining what font was used."This is not a pretty label designed to look good on the shelf," the owner continued."Its not a consumer product."This interference has stopped the distiller from shipping the cleansing gel and it cannot make any more at this stage, because it does not know whether it will be a wasted effort.In the worst-case scenario, council apparatchiks could order the company to apply for an EU license which would take upto  days to arrive."Its farcical," the owner continued."There has been an industry effort across Scotland and I believe Im the only one investigated by Trading Standards."There is a network of distillers across Scotland working to address the sanitiser shortfall in their area and I know for a fact that every single one of us is not doing this to make money."It is a stopgap until the normal supply chain comes back in operation - which could be four to six weeks away."In the meantime, Moray Council is like: Youre not conforming to regulations."The NHSdesperately needs this product."The final straw came when council officials spoke to the distiller asshe was planning a business."I wastold: Good luck with your venture."It beggars belief that this is their attitude towards this."Moray Council was unable to comment.

title: loganair announces further flight reductions and issues booking advice
story: Loganair have today announced further reductions in its flight schedules over the coming weeks, consistent with the Government’s efforts to contain the spread of the COVID- virus.A skeleton schedule of essential air services will operate within Scotland.All other Loganair routes and services are suspended from March  until at least April . Some will already have been closed for booking.Services relating to Orkney will be maintained to a limited timetable on the following routes with a minimum of six weekly flightsplanned:· Aberdeen-Kirkwall· Kirkwall-Sumburgh· Orkney inter-isles air services· Dedicated flights operated for Royal Mail and the oil and gas industryAt present, services are planned to resume on a selection of key routes from April  and on others from  May, but these dates will be subject to further review, depending on the prevailing national circumstances and consequent demand for travel.The services provided in the meantime will be to facilitate travel only for those with an essential need, such as workers in designated critical professions and others covered by the latest Government advice.Customers booked on routes which have been suspended or cancelled will be entitled to a refund of their ticket.Customers who wish to defer their travel plans or are unable to travel will be able to change their bookings without the usual change fees for a future date, or put flights “on hold” for up to six months via the “Manage my Booking” tab at www.loganair.Loganair’s call centre is operating with reduced capacity due to social distancing requirements to safeguard staff, and customers are asked not to call unless to discuss immediate travel needs in the next  hours. Please either manage your booking through the Loganair website or email bookings@loganair.Customers on flights which have been cancelled or rescheduled will be notied via the contacts provided to Loganair at the time of booking. The airline is asking customers with future bookings to keep an eye open for booking changes, especiallyimportant messages are caught in e-mail spam filters.Loganair expects to ground approximately half of its  aircraft in the coming days and has advised its staff of the probability of furlough under the Government’s Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme.The airline is also working to keep abreast of impending closures of several airport terminal facilities and to ensure contingency plans are available to continue to deliver these services eventhe usual airport terminals are not available to accommodate customers. Further information will be released once the need for such arrangements becomes clear.Efforts are also in hand to protect essential carriage of pharmaceuticals, mail, newspapers and other consumer goods which are reliant on Loganair’s services in the Highlands and Islands as a matter of course.Loganair’s Chief Executive Jonathan Hinkles said: “The challenges that we’re all facing in everyday le are evolving by the day, and we are having to work through a whole host of disparate issues to maintain services for those with a critical need to travel, or indeed the many island communities totally reliant on Loganair to deliver their daily essentials.“I’m proud of the work that so many of our team are doing right now to keep vital air routes open, without which our communities would be in severe dficulty. The tremendous team spirit in evidence throughout Loganair is providing all of us with confidence to tackle the challenges that undoubtedly lay ahead.”“Throughout all of this, safety will remain our absolute priority — whether that of our staff or our customers, or indeed the daily focus to assure that each and every Loganair flight is conducted safely.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: sqa suspends coursework submissions
story: vw, px"  The Scottish Qualications Authorityhas said that pupils undertaking Higher and Advance Higher courses will no longer be required to submit coursework. This also applies to any National Five coursework which was due to be uplted in April or May.The announcement came in a statement from the SQA, yesterday, Tuesday, following the latest guidance from the Scottish Government.Fiona Robertson, SQA chief executive and Scotland’s chief examiner said: #Following the announcement by the First Minister on Sunday, that no young person with SQA coursework to complete should attend school to do so, we continue to work hard on how we should take coursework evidence into account, in determining young people’s final grades.#Everyone here at SQA will do their utmost, given the current situation, and with the support of the education system, to ensure that learners’ hard work is rightly and fairly recognised and allows them to proceed to further learning or work.#The current public health advice has meant that we have had to make some really dficult decisions about coursework. This means that for this year, schools and colleges are not required to submit learner coursework for marking, in Higher and Advanced Higher courses.#We have taken this dficult decision to be as fair as possible to all Higher and Advanced Higher candidates, whilst taking on board the current public health advice, the many ied coursework requirements across dferent subjects, and how these are managed in schools and colleges across the country.#I appreciate that some learners may have already completed their coursework for Higher and Advanced Higher courses. This work can still be used as part of the suite of evidence for teachers and lecturers to draw on as they consider estimated grades.#We have received coursework for a range of National Five subjects and have contacted National Five coursework markers to confirm marking arrangements. All National Five coursework, due to be uplted in April and May, will not be submitted for marking.#We will provide further details on the estimation of grades, that we will need from teachers and lecturers to inform certication, and fuller details of our approach to certication, as soon as possible.#This is an unprecedented situation for us all, and circumstances are rapidly changing. With every change in circumstances, we continue to consider how best to recognise learner achievement in as fair a way as possible.#Please be assured that everyone here at SQA is fully committed to working with you to deliver for Scotland’s young people. Thank you for your patience and continued co-operation.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: stormont-leaders-defend-wait-ni-coronavirus-powers
story: Arlene Fosterand Michelle O’NeillStormontrsquos leaders have defended the time they are taking to agree Northern Irelandrsquos coronavirus enforcement regulations and guidance.Arlene Foster and Michelle OrsquoNeill insisted details of new police powers to fine those breaching social-distancing rules and a definitive list of essential businesses would be published as soon as possible.First Minister Mrs Foster acknowledged there was a need for clarity and predicted the regulations and guidance would be published by the end of the weekend,not earlier.Deputy First Minister Ms OrsquoNeill said she did not want to publish the regulations and guidance until they were ldquosolid, insisting that might create more questions than answers.The leaders have faced questions why the powersharing executive has still to implement the provisions of emergency legislation passed at Westminster earlier in the week.As of Friday evening, police still did not have the enforcement powers and many companies remained unclear as to whether they were considered an essential business.Despite the delay on the new powers, Mrs Foster said police could use powers already available to them to enforce appropriate behaviour over the coming weekend.ldquoPolice have their general laws, which of course they can use at any time, and they continue to do that and we understand from the Chief Constablethat he will enforce ndashhe believes that people are acting in a way that is injurious to public health ndash he will use those powers, she said.ldquoSo, itrsquos wrong to say that the police havenrsquot clarity in relation to any powers.Mrs Foster also announced the formation of a new forum to allow businesses and employee representatives to discuss concerns over safe working practices.Ms OrsquoNeill said the UK Governmentrsquos approach had hampered efforts to develop the new regulations and guidance.ldquoThis a rapidly changing situation ndash there arenrsquot answers to all the questions which title: imf-head-says-global-economy-recession
story: IMF managing director Kristalina GeorgievaThe head of the International Monetary Fundhas said the global economy has entered a recession that could be worse than the  downturn.IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva said the -nation lending agency is forecasting a recovery in , saying it could be a ldquosizeable rebound. But she said this would only occurnations succeed in containing coronavirus and limiting the economic damage.She said: ldquoA key concern about a long-lasting impact of the sudden stop of the world economy is the risk of a wave of bankruptcies and layoffs that not only can undermine the recovery but erode the fabric of our societies..@KGeorgieva: It is now clear that we have entered a recession. We project a rebound in , but onlywe contain the virus and prevent liquidity problems from becoming a solvency issue. https:t.co dgFHiuftW #COVID pic BIbFaRBumdash IMFMarch , She said the IMF is updating its economic outlook and it would be released in a few weeks, allowing the agency more time to assess the economic impacts of the virus.Askedthe United States was now in recession, she noted that Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell had said that America ldquomay well be in a recession.She said she believed not only the United States but many other advanced economies and a number of developing countries had already entered downturns.Mrs Georgieva said lower income countries were being hit hard by the spreading coronavirus, with  nations now seeking support from an IMF emergency financing programme being used to provide aid.She announced that Kyrgyzstan would receive the first IMF support package of . million US dollarsto deal with adverse effects of the virus..@KGeorgieva: We have seen an extraordinary spike in requests for IMF emergency financing ndash some  countries. We also see a range of problems building up in emerging market economies. #COVID pic WXpntJDDszmdash IMFMarch , She repeated a pledge that the IMF stood ready to make all  trillion dollars of its lending resources available to countries being hit by the virus.Mrs Georgieva said: ldquoWe have seen an extraordinary spike in requests for IMF emergency financing. We are being asked by our members to do more, do it better and do it faster than ever before.She said to meet the increased demand she would seek to double the emergency financing programme and simply the procedures countries will have to go through to obtain IMF support. She said the IMF was also looking for ways to expand its current lending facilities to provide more help to countries.Mrs Georgieva said the IMF also wanted to find ways to provide more debt relief to the poorest countries..@KGeorgieva: We are being asked by our member countries to do more, and to do it better and faster than ever before. Because of the virus, the spring meetings of both the IMF and its sister lending organisation, the World Bank, will be virtual this year instead of meetings in Washington.ldquoIMF efforts that start to offer debt relief to the poorest countries and that increase financing to help prevent a global financial crisis are really positive and needed steps, said Eric LeCompte, the executive director Jubilee USA, a group that campaigns for increased assistance for low income countries.copy -.
